    A custom Redux middleware is a function that intercepts actions before they reach the reducer. It can be used for logging, async calls, analytics, or side effects. A middleware follows the signature: store => next => action.

    Example: 
    
              const loggerMiddleware = store => next => action => {
                console.log('Dispatching:', action);
                const result = next(action);
                console.log('Next State:', store.getState());
                return result;
              };
    To apply it: const store = createStore(rootReducer, applyMiddleware(loggerMiddleware));
  • How do you perform optimistic updates in Redux?
    Optimistic updates in Redux update the UI immediately before the server confirms the change. You first update the local state assuming success, then confirm or rollback based on the API response.

    Steps:
    1. Dispatch an action that updates the UI instantly.
    2. Make the API call.
    3. On success, do nothing or confirm the state.
    4. On failure, dispatch a rollback action to revert the state.
    Use Case: Liking a post, moving a card in Trello, etc.
  • How does Redux Toolkit simplify reducer and action creation?
    Redux Toolkit provides utilities like createSlice that automatically generate action creators and reducers from a slice definition. It eliminates boilerplate and enforces best practices.

    Example: 
    
              const counterSlice = createSlice({
                name: 'counter',
                initialState: 0,
                reducers: {
                  increment: state => state + 1,
                  decrement: state => state - 1
                }
              });
              
              export const { increment, decrement } = counterSlice.actions;
              export default counterSlice.reducer;
    It also integrates with Immer to allow mutable-like syntax.
  • Explain the role of Immer in Redux Toolkit.
    Immer is a library that allows developers to write code that "mutates" state directly while preserving immutability under the hood. Redux Toolkit uses Immer in createSlice and createReducer so you can write simpler, cleaner reducers without needing to spread state manually.

    Example: 
    
              reducers: {
                increment: (state) => {
                  state.value += 1; // This is safe due to Immer
                }
              }
    Immer tracks the changes and produces a new immutable state object.
  • How do you reset a Redux store on user logout?
    To reset the Redux store on logout, you can:
    1. Dispatch a LOGOUT action.
    2. In the root reducer, intercept the logout action and return the initial state.
    3. Example root reducer setup: 
      
              const appReducer = combineReducers({ user, posts, auth });
              
              const rootReducer = (state, action) => {
                if (action.type === 'LOGOUT') {
                  state = undefined; // reset all state slices
                }
                return appReducer(state, action);
              };
    This ensures the entire Redux store is cleared and reinitialized.
  • How do you structure Redux modules in a large-scale application?
    Large-scale Redux applications typically follow a "feature-based" structure:
    • Each feature folder contains its own slice, actions, reducers, selectors, and tests.
    • Use Redux Toolkit's createSlice to encapsulate logic.
    • Example folder structure: 
                    src/
                features/
                  auth/
                    authSlice.js
                    authActions.js
                    authSelectors.js
                    authAPI.js
                  posts/
                    postSlice.js
                    postSelectors.js
                    postAPI.js
                    postComponents/
    • This promotes modularity, testability, and separation of concerns.
  • What are the limitations of the connect HOC in modern Redux apps?
    • Boilerplate: Requires mapStateToProps, mapDispatchToProps, and verbose syntax.
    • Component Nesting: Makes composition harder due to HOC wrapping.
    • Loss of Hooks Advantage: Not compatible with useSelector or useDispatch.
    • Testability: Harder to test compared to hooks-based components.
    • Modern Best Practice: React-Redux now recommends hooks (e.g., useSelector, useDispatch) for better readability and co-located logic.
  • How can Redux selectors help in optimizing performance?
    Selectors are pure functions used to extract slices of state. When memoized (e.g., using reselect), they prevent unnecessary recomputations and reduce re-renders:
    • Memoization: Ensures recalculation happens only when relevant state changes.
    • Derived Data: Allows transformation of state efficiently without storing redundant values.
    • Component Optimization: Using selectors with useSelector avoids triggering rerenders on unrelated state updates.
    • Example with reselect: 
      
              import { createSelector } from 'reselect';
              
              const getUsers = (state) => state.users;
              const getActiveUsers = createSelector(
                [getUsers],
                (users) => users.filter(u => u.active)
              );
  • What is reselect?
    Reselect is a library for creating memoized selectors in Redux.

    Selectors are functions used to extract specific pieces of state. Reselect helps avoid unnecessary recalculations by memoizing the result based on input parameters.

    Example: 
                  import { createSelector } from 'reselect';
              
              const selectUsers = state => state.users;
              const selectActiveUsers = createSelector(
                [selectUsers],
                (users) => users.filter(user => user.active)
              );
    Benefits:
    • Improves performance by preventing re-renders on unchanged data.
    • Encourages clean separation of state access and computation.
    • Supports composable, reusable logic for derived state.
  • How do you persist Redux state?
    Redux state persistence allows your app to maintain state across reloads or app restarts.

    Common approach: redux-persist
    • Install redux-persist and configure your store with a persistReducer.
    • Wrap your root reducer with persistReducer and use persistStore.
    • Wrap your app with PersistGate to delay rendering until the state is rehydrated.
    Example: 
                    import storage from 'redux-persist/lib/storage';
                import { persistReducer, persistStore } from 'redux-persist';
                
                const persistConfig = {
                  key: 'root',
                  storage,
                };
                
                const persistedReducer = persistReducer(persistConfig, rootReducer);
                
                const store = configureStore({ reducer: persistedReducer });
                const persistor = persistStore(store);
    Alternatives:
    • Custom localStorage or sessionStorage logic using store.subscribe.
    • Persist only selected slices for better performance.
  • What are Redux Toolkit and its advantages?
    Redux Toolkit is the official, recommended way to write Redux logic. It abstracts and simplifies Redux boilerplate.

    Advantages:
    • Reduces boilerplate with createSlice, createReducer, createAsyncThunk, etc.
    • Includes Immer to handle immutable updates with mutable code style.
    • Built-in integration with Redux DevTools and middleware setup.
    • Supports code splitting and modular architecture.
    • Improves maintainability, readability, and testability.
    • Comes with powerful utilities like createEntityAdapter and RTK Query.
    Conclusion: Redux Toolkit simplifies Redux adoption and makes it more approachable and scalable.
  • What is createSlice in Redux Toolkit?
    createSlice is a helper function in Redux Toolkit that combines reducer logic and action creators in a single unit.

    Key features:
    • Automatically generates action types and creators based on reducer functions.
    • Integrates with Immer to write reducers that use mutating logic.
    • Returns an object with reducer and actions for easy export.
    Example: 
                    const counterSlice = createSlice({
                  name: 'counter',
                  initialState: { value: 0 },
                  reducers: {
                    increment: state => { state.value += 1 },
                    decrement: state => { state.value -= 1 },
                  }
                });
                
                export const { increment, decrement } = counterSlice.actions;
                export default counterSlice.reducer;
    Benefit: Cleaner, more maintainable Redux logic with less boilerplate.
  • How is createAsyncThunk used?
    createAsyncThunk is a Redux Toolkit utility that simplifies writing async logic like fetching data from APIs.

    Usage steps:
    1. Define the thunk with a type and payload creator.
    2. Use it in a slice via extraReducers to handle pending, fulfilled, and rejected actions.
    Example: 
                      const fetchUser = createAsyncThunk('user/fetch', async (id) => {
                    const response = await fetch(`/api/users/${id}`);
                    return await response.json();
                  });
                  
                  extraReducers: builder => {
                    builder
                      .addCase(fetchUser.pending, state => { state.loading = true })
                      .addCase(fetchUser.fulfilled, (state, action) => {
                        state.user = action.payload;
                        state.loading = false;
                      })
                      .addCase(fetchUser.rejected, state => { state.loading = false });
                  }
    Benefits: Automatically dispatches lifecycle actions and handles promise resolution.
  • What is the difference between redux and @reduxjs/toolkit?
    redux is the core library providing store, reducers, actions, and middleware setup ‚Äî minimal but verbose.

    @reduxjs/toolkit is the official abstraction that simplifies Redux usage and includes helpful utilities.

    Key differences:
    • Redux requires manual setup; Toolkit provides configureStore with sane defaults.
    • Toolkit includes utilities like createSlice, createAsyncThunk, and createEntityAdapter.
    • Toolkit uses Immer internally for writing mutable update logic safely.
    • Toolkit enforces best practices and encourages modular code organization.
    Conclusion: Use Redux Toolkit as the default way to build Redux apps.
  • How can Redux help with state management in large apps?
    Redux provides a predictable, centralized state container that helps manage complex and shared state in large applications.

    Benefits in large apps:
    • Single source of truth: Easier debugging and data flow understanding.
    • Unidirectional data flow: Reduces confusion and side effects.
    • Scalability: Can modularize features via slices and combineReducers.
    • Middleware: Helps manage side effects, logging, analytics, etc.
    • DevTools: Supports time-travel debugging and state inspection.
    • SSR support: Easily hydrate and share state between server and client.
    Toolkit tools like RTK Query and entity adapters further improve scalability and performance.
  • How do you write tests for Redux reducers?
    Redux reducers are pure functions and easy to test in isolation with standard unit tests.

    Steps:
    1. Import the reducer and define an initial state.
    2. Dispatch actions and assert the returned state.
    Example: 
                      test('should handle increment', () => {
                    const state = { value: 0 };
                    const nextState = counterReducer(state, increment());
                    expect(nextState.value).toBe(1);
                  });
    Tips:
    • Test edge cases like undefined state or unknown action types.
    • Use slice.actions directly for clean and accurate tests.
    • Test async thunks separately using mock stores or mocking APIs.
  • What is the role of immutability in Redux?
    Immutability ensures that Redux state updates are predictable and traceable. It allows Redux to:
    • Detect changes using shallow comparison (e.g., in useSelector or connect).
    • Enable time-travel debugging and state history tracking.
    • Prevent unintended side effects or accidental state corruption.
    Immutability guarantees: When state changes, a new object is returned instead of modifying the existing one.
  • What happens if you mutate the Redux state directly?
    Mutating Redux state directly breaks the core principles of Redux and causes issues such as:
    • Components not re-rendering because shallow comparison fails to detect changes.
    • DevTools and time-travel debugging becoming inaccurate.
    • Unpredictable bugs due to shared mutable references.
    Always return a new state object in reducers instead of mutating the existing one.

    Note: Redux Toolkit uses Immer internally, allowing you to write "mutating" code that remains immutable under the hood.
  • How do you structure a large Redux application?
    Large Redux apps benefit from modular, scalable architecture. Best practices include:
    • Feature-based folders: Group files by feature instead of type.
    • Slice per feature: Use createSlice for each domain or module.
    • Normalized state: Use createEntityAdapter to avoid nested structures.
    • Async logic: Use createAsyncThunk and middleware for side effects.
    • Lazy loading: Split reducers with combineReducers and dynamic reducer injection.
    Example structure: 
                        src/
                     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ features/
                         ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ users/
                         ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ userSlice.js
                         ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ UserList.jsx
                         ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ posts/
                             ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ postSlice.js
                             ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ PostList.jsx
  • What are some alternatives to Redux?
    While Redux is powerful, other tools can be better suited depending on the app's complexity:
    • Context API: Good for lightweight global state without middleware.
    • Zustand: A small, minimal state management library with a simple API.
    • Recoil: Offers fine-grained reactivity and better support for derived state.
    • Jotai: Atom-based state management that scales well with small footprint.
    • MobX: Uses observables for automatic reactivity, suitable for large dynamic UIs.
    • React Query or SWR: For server state, caching, and data synchronization.
    Choose based on your app's needs: Redux is best when complex state, debugging, or middleware is required.
  • What is the difference between Redux and Context API?
    Both Redux and Context API help manage state globally in React applications, but they serve different purposes.

    Context API:
    • Ideal for low-frequency, simple state sharing (e.g., themes, user data).
    • Does not provide built-in support for middleware, devtools, or immutability.
    • Prone to performance issues due to unnecessary re-renders when state updates.
    Redux:
    • Designed for complex state management with predictable state transitions.
    • Supports middleware, time-travel debugging, and DevTools integration.
    • Highly testable and scalable with proper architecture (slices, selectors, thunks).
    Conclusion: Use Context for simple scenarios and Redux when managing large or complex state logic.
  • How do you debug Redux applications?
    Debugging Redux apps is straightforward due to its predictable state flow and DevTools support.

    Common debugging techniques:
    • Use Redux DevTools to inspect dispatched actions and resulting state changes.
    • Log actions and states with custom or built-in middleware.
    • Use selectors to isolate and test state-derived values.
    • Test reducers independently using unit tests.
    • Use Redux Toolkit‚Äôs built-in error messages and immutability checks.
    Tip: Avoid mutating state directly and ensure every reducer returns new state objects.
  • What is Redux DevTools?
    Redux DevTools is a browser extension that helps you debug Redux applications.

    Key features:
    • View all dispatched actions and the resulting state.
    • Time-travel debugging: step forward and backward through state changes.
    • Track action history and replay them.
    • Inspect the state tree at any point in time.
    • Export/import state snapshots for troubleshooting.
    Integration: Redux Toolkit's configureStore enables DevTools by default.
  • What is a selector in Redux?
    A selector is a function that extracts and returns a specific part of the Redux state.

    Benefits of selectors:
    • Encapsulate logic for retrieving data from the state tree.
    • Make components cleaner and more reusable.
    • Improve testability and maintainability.
    • Can be memoized using libraries like Reselect for performance optimization.
    Example: A selector can retrieve all posts, filtered posts, or a post by ID.
  • What is the useSelector hook?
    The useSelector hook is a React-Redux function that allows functional components to access the Redux store's state.

    Key points:
    • Replaces the mapStateToProps function used in connect.
    • Automatically subscribes the component to Redux store updates.
    • Performs a shallow comparison to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
    • You pass a selector function that returns the required slice of state.
  • What is the useDispatch hook?
    The useDispatch hook provides access to the Redux store's dispatch function in React functional components.

    Key points:
    • Allows you to dispatch actions directly from a component.
    • Replaces the mapDispatchToProps used in connect.
    • Works well with action creators and async thunks from Redux Toolkit.
    • Typically used in combination with useSelector for full Redux integration.
  • Can Redux be used without React?
    Yes, Redux is a standalone JavaScript library that can be used with any UI framework or even without a UI.

    Use cases beyond React:
    • Vanilla JavaScript apps for managing complex state.
    • Integration with other frameworks like Angular or Vue.
    • Node.js services or command-line applications.
    Conclusion: React-Redux is just the glue library for integrating Redux with React.
  • How do you handle async operations in Redux?
    Redux handles async operations like API calls using middleware.

    Common approaches:
    • Redux Thunk: Allows you to write action creators that return functions instead of plain objects.
    • Redux Saga: Uses generator functions to manage async flows more declaratively.
    • Redux Toolkit: Includes createAsyncThunk to simplify async logic and side-effect handling.
    Best practice: Keep async logic outside reducers and handle it in middleware or thunks.
  • How do you connect a React component to the Redux store?
    You can connect a React component to the Redux store using either the connect higher-order component or the useSelector and useDispatch hooks.

    Using connect:
    • Use mapStateToProps to read state.
    • Use mapDispatchToProps to dispatch actions.
    Using hooks:
    • useSelector to select state values.
    • useDispatch to dispatch actions.
    Best practice: Prefer hooks in modern React apps for cleaner, functional components.
  • What are the pros and cons of using Redux?
    Redux is a powerful state management tool, but it's not always necessary.

    Pros:
    • Centralized and predictable state management.
    • Debugging tools like time-travel and action logging.
    • Middleware support for side effects and async logic.
    • Well-suited for large, complex applications.
    Cons:
    • Boilerplate code, especially without Redux Toolkit.
    • Overhead for simple state needs.
    • Steeper learning curve for beginners.
    • Requires careful structure to avoid state bloat.
  • What is mapStateToProps?
    mapStateToProps is a function used with the connect method to specify which parts of the Redux state the component should receive as props.

    Purpose:
    • Extract only the required state slices for the component.
    • Improves performance by limiting unnecessary re-renders.
    Example: mapStateToProps can return an object like count or user data that is mapped to component props.
  • What is mapDispatchToProps?
    mapDispatchToProps is used with the connect function to map action creators to component props, allowing components to dispatch actions.

    Options:
    • Pass an object of action creators to auto-bind them.
    • Pass a function for custom logic or conditional dispatch.
    Benefit: Makes components unaware of the Redux store by abstracting dispatch.
  • What is the difference between connect and hooks like useSelector and useDispatch?
    connect:
    • Used in class components or legacy codebases.
    • Involves mapStateToProps and mapDispatchToProps.
    • Can be more verbose but useful for separation of concerns.
    Hooks:
    • Designed for functional components using useSelector and useDispatch.
    • Simpler syntax and less boilerplate.
    • More idiomatic in modern React with hooks.
    Conclusion: Hooks are preferred for new React apps; connect is still valid for class-based components.
  • What is middleware in Redux?
    Middleware in Redux is a function that sits between the action being dispatched and the reducer receiving the action.

    Purpose:
    • Intercept actions before they reach reducers.
    • Enable async operations, logging, crash reporting, etc.
    • Enhance store capabilities without modifying Redux core.
  • How does Redux middleware work?
    Redux middleware provides a third-party extension point between dispatching an action and the moment it reaches the reducer.

    Workflow:
    • The middleware receives the store‚Äôs dispatch and getState functions.
    • It returns a function that takes the next middleware or reducer.
    • That in turn returns a function that takes an action.
    • You can then intercept, modify, or delay actions before passing them on.
  • What is redux-thunk?
    redux-thunk is a middleware that allows you to write action creators that return a function instead of an action object.

    Key features:
    • Handles async operations like API calls inside action creators.
    • Gives access to dispatch and getState inside the returned function.
    • Allows complex logic like conditionals and side effects in actions.
  • What is redux-saga?
    redux-saga is a middleware that uses generator functions to handle complex side effects in Redux applications.

    Key features:
    • Declarative: you describe what should happen, not how.
    • Handles race conditions, retries, and concurrency better than thunk.
    • Makes testable and maintainable async logic via generator functions.
    • Works well for long-running background tasks and flows.
  • How do you integrate Redux with React?
    Redux is integrated with React using the react-redux library, which provides the Provider component and hooks like useSelector and useDispatch.

    Steps:
    • Create a Redux store using configureStore or createStore.
    • Wrap the root React component with the Provider and pass the store.
    • Use useSelector to read state and useDispatch to send actions.
    Best practice: Use Redux Toolkit for easier setup and modern patterns.
  • What is the role of the Provider component in Redux?
    The Provider component is a React component that makes the Redux store available to all nested components.

    Role:
    • Wraps the root of the app to pass down the store using React context.
    • Enables useSelector and useDispatch to access the Redux state and dispatch actions.
    • Ensures all components in the tree have access to the global store.
  • What is a Redux store?
    The Redux store is a centralized container that holds the entire application's state.

    Key responsibilities:
    • Holds the current state tree of the app.
    • Allows access to state via getState.
    • Allows state to be updated via dispatching actions.
    • Registers listeners via subscribe.
    • Handles updates through reducers.
  • What is an action in Redux?
    An action in Redux is a plain JavaScript object that describes an intention to change the state.

    Structure:
    • Must have a type property (string).
    • May include a payload with additional data.
    Example: { type: "INCREMENT", payload: 1 }
  • What is a reducer in Redux?
    A reducer is a pure function that takes the current state and an action, and returns a new state.

    Key properties:
    • Must be a pure function (no side effects).
    • Should return the initial state if undefined.
    • Must not mutate the original state directly.
    Purpose: Defines how state changes in response to actions.
  • How do you dispatch an action in Redux?
    You dispatch an action using the store's dispatch method or using useDispatch in React-Redux.

    Methods:
    • store.dispatch({ type: "INCREMENT" })
    • useDispatch()(action) inside functional components
    Effect: The action is sent to reducers to compute the new state.
  • What is the purpose of the combineReducers function?
    The combineReducers function is used to split the Redux state management logic into multiple reducer functions.

    Benefits:
    • Improves code organization and modularity.
    • Each reducer manages its own slice of state.
    • Creates a root reducer to be passed to the Redux store.
    Structure: The shape of the Redux state mirrors the keys passed to combineReducers.
  • What is Redux?
    Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript applications. It helps manage and centralize application state using a unidirectional data flow.

    Key characteristics:
    • Single source of truth
    • State is read-only (immutable)
    • Changes are made via pure functions called reducers
  • Why use Redux in a React application?
    Redux helps manage state in medium to large React applications where state needs to be shared between multiple components.

    Benefits:
    • Centralizes state and logic in a predictable manner
    • Makes debugging easier with tools like Redux DevTools
    • Improves maintainability and testability of state logic
    • Enables features like undo/redo, logging, and state persistence
  • What are the core principles of Redux?
    Redux is built on three core principles:

    • Single source of truth: The state of the entire application is stored in a single object tree within a single store.
    • State is read-only: The only way to change the state is by emitting an action, an object describing what happened.
    • Changes are made with pure functions: To specify how the state tree is transformed by actions, you write pure reducers.
  • Explain the Redux data flow architecture.
    Redux follows a strict unidirectional data flow, which ensures that the state changes in a predictable way.

    Flow steps:
    1. An action is dispatched by the UI or a middleware.
    2. The action is sent to the reducer.
    3. The reducer calculates a new state based on the current state and action.
    4. The Redux store updates the state and notifies the subscribed components.
    5. The React components re-render with the updated state.
    This pattern ensures a consistent and traceable state update process.
  • What is the difference between useSelector and mapStateToProps?
    • useSelector is a React-Redux hook used in functional components to access the Redux store directly.
    • mapStateToProps is a function used with the connect() HOC to map state to props in class-based or wrapped components.
    • Differences:
      • useSelector leads to cleaner, hook-based code and works only in functional components.
      • mapStateToProps is useful in older codebases and supports memoization via reselect.
      • useSelector provides more direct and modular access to state.
  • How do you use Redux Toolkit‚Äôs createEntityAdapter?
    createEntityAdapter helps manage normalized state for collections (e.g., lists of items). It provides prebuilt reducers and selectors.

    Usage: 
    
              import { createSlice, createEntityAdapter } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
              
              const booksAdapter = createEntityAdapter();
              
              const booksSlice = createSlice({
                name: 'books',
                initialState: booksAdapter.getInitialState(),
                reducers: {
                  bookAdded: booksAdapter.addOne,
                  booksReceived: booksAdapter.setAll,
                }
              });
              
              export const bookSelectors = booksAdapter.getSelectors(state => state.books);
    This results in efficient and scalable list handling with automatic ID-based updates.
  • How can Redux state be hydrated from the server?
    Server-side hydration involves injecting server-fetched data into the Redux store during initial render.
    Steps:
    1. Fetch data on the server (e.g., in Next.js‚Äôs getServerSideProps).
    2. Dispatch actions to populate Redux state.
    3. Pass the preloaded state to the client via <script> or props.
    4. On the client, initialize the store with this state: 
      
              const store = configureStore({ preloadedState: window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ });
    This ensures consistency between server-rendered and client-rendered content.
  • What are the benefits of colocating Redux slices with features?
    Colocating Redux slices means placing reducers, actions, selectors, and related logic within the same folder as the feature/component it serves.
    Benefits:
    • Modularity: Each feature manages its own state, reducing tight coupling.
    • Scalability: New features can be added independently with minimal global impact.
    • Maintainability: Easier to locate and update related logic.
    • Testability: Tests for actions and reducers live alongside their logic.
    • Cleaner Codebase: Avoids bloated global Redux folders.
  • How do you debug deeply nested Redux state?
    Debugging deeply nested state in Redux can be tackled through:
    • Redux DevTools: Use the time-travel debugger to inspect state changes visually and drill down into nested trees.
    • Selectors: Create specific selectors for nested parts of the state to isolate and log only what you need.
    • Logging Middleware: Add a custom middleware or use libraries like redux-logger to log before/after state snapshots.
    • Component Isolation: Use useSelector hooks to inspect specific branches of state in functional components.
    • Immutable Debugging: Use tools like immer + redux-immutable-state-invariant to catch mutation issues in dev mode.
  • What is a normalized state structure in Redux?
    A normalized state structure in Redux organizes data similar to a relational database, using IDs as keys to eliminate duplication and improve performance.
    Benefits:
    • Faster updates (update by ID).
    • Avoids redundant or nested copies of data.
    • Makes caching, pagination, and relationships easier.
    Example: 
    
              {
                users: {
                  byId: {
                    1: { id: 1, name: 'Alice' },
                    2: { id: 2, name: 'Bob' }
                  },
                  allIds: [1, 2]
                }
              }
    Tool: Redux Toolkit‚Äôs createEntityAdapter helps structure state this way automatically.
  • How does Redux support SSR (Server-Side Rendering)?
    Redux supports SSR by preloading data on the server, injecting it into the Redux store, and rendering the app with that store‚Äôs state.
    Workflow:
    1. On server: create the Redux store and dispatch any async actions (e.g., fetch data).
    2. Wait for all actions to resolve.
    3. Render the app to HTML using ReactDOMServer.renderToString().
    4. Serialize the store state into the HTML response.
    5. On client: rehydrate the Redux store with the preloaded state.
    Example: Frameworks like Next.js automate this with getServerSideProps and a shared store between server and client.
  • What are Redux enhancers and how are they different from middleware?
    Redux Enhancers are higher-order functions that enhance the behavior of the Redux store itself. They wrap createStore and can modify how the store behaves.

    Middleware, on the other hand, sits between dispatching an action and the moment it reaches the reducer, intercepting or modifying actions.

    Key Differences:
    • Enhancers: Modify the store capabilities (e.g., Redux DevTools, applyMiddleware).
    • Middleware: Intercept actions (e.g., redux-thunk, redux-logger).
    • Usage: 
      
              const store = createStore(
                rootReducer,
                compose(applyMiddleware(thunk), customEnhancer)
              );
  • How do you use Redux in a React Native app?
    Using Redux in a React Native app is almost the same as in React web apps:
    1. Install Redux and React-Redux: 
      npm install redux react-redux @reduxjs/toolkit
    2. Create your store and slices using Redux Toolkit.
    3. Wrap the root component with <Provider store={store} /> in App.js.
    4. Use useSelector and useDispatch inside your components.
    5. Persist state using redux-persist if needed for offline apps.
    Note: React Native does not support Redux DevTools out of the box, but you can use remote-redux-devtools or similar libraries for debugging.
  • What are common performance pitfalls in Redux?
    Common performance issues in Redux apps:
    • Overuse of global state: Storing local UI state in Redux causes unnecessary rerenders.
    • Unoptimized selectors: Avoid re-creating derived data every time. Use reselect for memoization.
    • Large reducers: Long switch-cases make logic hard to test and scale.
    • Incorrect useSelector usage: Avoid passing entire objects. Compare primitive values or use memoized selectors.
    • Frequent re-renders: Connected components rerender more often than needed if not properly memoized with React.memo.
    • Heavy dev logging: Avoid deep state logs in production.
    • No batching: Dispatching many actions in sequence without batching leads to poor performance.
    Best Practice: Use Redux Toolkit, memoized selectors, and split feature slices.
  • ---------------------------------------------
  • -------------- ReactJS -------------------
  • ---------------------------------------------
  • RxJS Required

    Is RxJS Required for ReactJS?

    No, RxJS is not required for building ReactJS applications, but it can be useful in specific use cases.

    ‚úÖ When RxJS is NOT Required

    • Basic forms and inputs
    • Using Axios or fetch for API calls
    • State management with Redux Toolkit or Context API
    • Handling async logic with redux-thunk or redux-saga
    • Real-time features using WebSocket without Observables

    ‚úÖ When RxJS is Useful or Recommended

    RxJS is helpful in advanced scenarios like:

    Use Case Why RxJS is Helpful
    Real-time data streams Handles async streams efficiently using Observables
    Debounced search or auto-suggestions Operators like debounceTime and distinctUntilChanged make it easy
    Multi-step async workflows Simplifies chaining and canceling requests
    Combining multiple async sources Use operators like combineLatest and merge
    Using redux-observable RxJS is required to work with Epics

    ‚úÖ Summary

    Question Answer
    Is RxJS required for ReactJS? ‚ùå No
    Is RxJS useful for complex async or stream-based logic? ‚úÖ Yes
    Common combo React + RxJS + redux-observable

    RxJS with React ‚Äì Complete Guide

    RxJS (Reactive Extensions for JavaScript) is a library for reactive programming using Observables, to make it easier to work with asynchronous or callback-based code.

    üåü What is RxJS?

    • RxJS provides a way to create and manage asynchronous data streams.
    • It uses Observables to emit values over time and allows operators like debounce, map, merge, filter, etc.
    • It helps manage data flow from multiple sources like WebSocket, API responses, user input, etc.

    üîó Why Use RxJS in React?

    • Powerful control over async streams (debounce, throttle, retry, cancel requests)
    • Can handle complex interactions and side effects
    • Helps in auto-complete inputs, search bars, or WebSocket data streams
    • Works great with libraries like redux-observable

    ‚öôÔ∏è Core Concepts in RxJS

    Concept Description
    Observable Represents a stream of values emitted over time
    Observer An object with next, error, and complete methods to react to emitted values
    Subscription Represents execution of Observable and is used to unsubscribe
    Operators Functions to transform or filter data (e.g., map, filter, debounceTime)
    Subject Both an Observable and Observer; can multicast values to multiple subscribers

    üìå Use Cases in React

    • Search with debounce: Prevents API calls for every keystroke
    • Auto-complete suggestions: Emits values based on input changes
    • Live updates with WebSocket: Streams real-time data to the UI
    • Handling cancelable async tasks: Abort previous API requests easily

    üß™ Example: Debounced Search Input

    1. Use RxJS Subject to collect user input events
    2. Apply debounceTime to wait for a pause in typing
    3. Subscribe to the stream and make API calls
    4. Update the component state with the search result

    üìö Libraries and Tools

    • rxjs ‚Äì core reactive library
    • redux-observable ‚Äì middleware for Redux using RxJS Epics
    • recompose (deprecated) ‚Äì used to integrate observables into React

    ‚úÖ When to Use RxJS

    • Advanced apps needing stream-based logic
    • Real-time dashboards and WebSocket integrations
    • Custom hooks that deal with user input and APIs
    • Replacing complex promise chains

    ‚ùå When Not to Use RxJS

    • Simple projects with minimal async logic
    • When Redux Toolkit or useEffect with fetch is sufficient
    • If team is not familiar with reactive programming concepts

    üß† Learning Curve

    RxJS is powerful but has a steep learning curve. It requires understanding observables, operators, subscriptions, and error handling properly. Once mastered, it‚Äôs a strong tool for managing complex side effects and data flows.

    üéØ Summary

    Feature RxJS in React
    Required for React? No
    Great for complex async workflows? Yes
    Ideal for search debounce, real-time, cancelable tasks? Yes
    Used with redux-observable? Yes
    Beginner-friendly? No, requires learning curve
  • Cookie vs LocalStorage
    Feature localStorage Cookies
    Storage Capacity ~5MB per domain ~4KB per cookie
    Data Lifetime Stays until manually cleared Can have expiration date (e.g., 7 days)
    Automatic Server Access Not sent with HTTP requests Automatically sent with every HTTP request
    Usage in React Storing UI state, theme, tokens (client-only) Storing session data, auth tokens, CSRF protection
    Security Vulnerable to XSS Can use HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags
    Accessibility Accessible via JavaScript only Accessible by both client and server
    Expiration Control Must be cleared manually Can set expiration per cookie
    Best Use Cases Theme, preferences, client cache Auth tokens, sessions, secure data

  • Why do we use Express.js?
    Express.js is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for building web and mobile applications. Key reasons for using Express.js include:
    • Simplicity and Minimalism: Express offers a clean and minimal interface to build servers and APIs quickly.
    • Routing: Built-in robust routing system to handle different HTTP methods and URLs easily.
    • Middleware Support: Enables modular code with middleware functions for handling requests, responses, logging, authentication, etc.
    • Performance: Built on top of Node.js, it is fast and non-blocking, suitable for scalable applications.
    • Community and Ecosystem: Large community support and a vast ecosystem of third-party middleware and plugins.
    • Integration: Easily integrates with databases like MongoDB, MySQL, and tools like Socket.IO or templating engines.
    • RESTful API Support: Ideal for creating RESTful APIs and microservices architectures.
  • How is error handling done in React.js?
    Error handling in React.js can be done using several approaches to ensure robust UI and graceful error recovery:
    • Error Boundaries: React components that catch JavaScript errors in their child component tree, log them, and display a fallback UI instead of crashing the app. 
      
class ErrorBoundary extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props);
    this.state = { hasError: false };
  }
  static getDerivedStateFromError(error) {
    return { hasError: true };
  }
  componentDidCatch(error, info) {
    console.error("Error caught:", error, info);
  }
  render() {
    if (this.state.hasError) {
      return <h1>Something went wrong.</h1>;
    }
    return this.props.children;
  }
}
    • Try-Catch Blocks: Use inside event handlers or async functions to catch runtime errors. 
      
try {
  const response = await fetch("/api/data");
  const data = await response.json();
  setData(data);
} catch (error) {
  console.error("Fetch error:", error);
}
    • React Hook Error Handling: Handle errors in custom hooks or `useEffect` using try-catch patterns.
    • Global Error Logging: Use tools like Sentry, LogRocket, or custom logging to capture and report runtime exceptions.
    • Form Error Handling: Use libraries like Formik or React Hook Form to validate input and show errors to users.
  • How is error handling done in Node.js?
    Error handling in Node.js is crucial for building reliable applications and involves managing synchronous and asynchronous errors effectively. Common techniques include:
    • Try-Catch Blocks (Synchronous Code): Used to catch errors in synchronous code blocks. 
      
try {
  let result = riskyFunction();
  console.log(result);
} catch (error) {
  console.error("Caught error:", error);
}
    • Callback Pattern (Asynchronous): Traditional Node.js style using error-first callbacks. 
      
fs.readFile('file.txt', (err, data) => {
  if (err) {
    return console.error("Read error:", err);
  }
  console.log(data.toString());
});
    • Promises & Async/Await: Handle asynchronous code with try-catch and `.catch()`. 
      
async function fetchData() {
  try {
    const res = await fetch("https://api.example.com");
    const data = await res.json();
    console.log(data);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Async error:", error);
  }
}
    • Global Error Handlers: Catch uncaught exceptions and unhandled promise rejections. 
      
process.on("uncaughtException", (err) => {
  console.error("Uncaught Exception:", err);
});
process.on("unhandledRejection", (reason, promise) => {
  console.error("Unhandled Rejection:", reason);
});
    • Express Error Middleware: Centralized error handling in Express.js. 
      
app.use((err, req, res, next) => {
  console.error("Error:", err.message);
  res.status(500).json({ error: "Something went wrong!" });
});
  • How is data sharing handled in Next.js?
    In Next.js, data sharing between components and pages can be achieved using various methods depending on the context and requirements:
    • Props: The most basic method. Data is passed from parent to child components using props. 
      
export default function Parent() {
  return <Child message="Hello from parent!" />;
}
    • Context API: For sharing global state across multiple components without prop drilling. 
      
const MyContext = React.createContext();
export function MyProvider({ children }) {
  const [user, setUser] = useState(null);
  return (
    <MyContext.Provider value={{ user, setUser }}>
      {children}
    </MyContext.Provider>
  );
}
    • Custom Hooks: Encapsulate logic and shared state in reusable hooks. 
      
function useAuth() {
  const [user, setUser] = useState(null);
  return { user, login: () => setUser({ name: "Dev" }) };
}
    • Server-side Sharing (getServerSideProps / getStaticProps): Share fetched data with pages at request/build time. 
      
export async function getServerSideProps() {
  const res = await fetch("https://api.example.com/data");
  const data = await res.json();
  return { props: { data } };
}
    • URL Query Parameters: Pass and share lightweight data via the query string. 
      
const router = useRouter();
console.log(router.query.id);
    • State Management Libraries: Use tools like Redux, Zustand, or Recoil for complex or large-scale data sharing across the app.
  • Is Redux usable in Next.js?
    Yes, Redux can be used in Next.js to manage global state across components and pages. It is especially useful for large applications where complex state logic needs to be shared. Here's how Redux works with Next.js:
    • Integration with SSR: Next.js supports server-side rendering (SSR), and Redux can be integrated with SSR using libraries like next-redux-wrapper to ensure state hydration across client and server.
    • Installation: 
      
npm install redux react-redux next-redux-wrapper
    • Store Configuration: Create a Redux store and wrap the app using Provider and createWrapper. 
      
// store.js
import { configureStore } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
import counterReducer from './counterSlice';

export const store = () => configureStore({ reducer: { counter: counterReducer } });
        
      
// _app.js
import { Provider } from 'react-redux';
import { wrapper } from './store';

function MyApp({ Component, ...rest }) {
  const { store, props } = wrapper.useWrappedStore(rest);
  return (
    <Provider store={store}>
      <Component {...props.pageProps} />
    </Provider>
  );
}

export default MyApp;
    • Accessing State: Use Redux hooks like useSelector and useDispatch inside components. 
      
import { useSelector, useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
const count = useSelector(state => state.counter.value);
const dispatch = useDispatch();
    • SSR Compatibility: Redux state can be preloaded in getServerSideProps or getStaticProps using store.dispatch().
    Conclusion: Redux works very well in Next.js, especially when using next-redux-wrapper to support SSR and CSR (Client-Side Rendering).
  • Redux with Next.js App Router (App Directory)

    Folder Structure:

    
redux-nextjs-app-router/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ layout.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ page.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ providers.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompA.js
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompB.js
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CompC.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ store/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ counterSlice.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ store.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json

    1. store/counterSlice.js

    
import { createSlice } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';

const counterSlice = createSlice({
  name: 'counter',
  initialState: { value: 0 },
  reducers: {
    increment: state => { state.value += 1 },
    decrement: state => { state.value -= 1 },
    reset: state => { state.value = 0 },
  }
});

export const { increment, decrement, reset } = counterSlice.actions;
export default counterSlice.reducer;

    2. store/store.js

    
import { configureStore } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
import counterReducer from './counterSlice';

export const store = configureStore({
  reducer: { counter: counterReducer }
});

    3. app/providers.js

    
'use client';
import { Provider } from 'react-redux';
import { store } from '../store/store';

export function Providers({ children }) {
  return <Provider store={store}>{children}</Provider>;
}

    4. app/layout.js

    
import './globals.css';
import { Providers } from './providers';

export const metadata = {
  title: 'Redux App Router',
  description: 'Next.js 13 App Router with Redux',
};

export default function RootLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <body>
        <Providers>{children}</Providers>
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}

    5. app/page.js

    
import CompA from './components/CompA';
import CompB from './components/CompB';
import CompC from './components/CompC';

export default function HomePage() {
  return (
    <main style={{ padding: 20 }}>
      <h1>Redux + App Router Example</h1>
      <CompA />
      <CompB />
      <CompC />
    </main>
  );
}

    6. app/components/CompA.js

    
'use client';
import { useSelector } from 'react-redux';

export default function CompA() {
  const count = useSelector((state) => state.counter.value);
  return <h2>CompA - Counter: {count}</h2>;
}

    7. app/components/CompB.js

    
'use client';
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { increment, decrement } from '../../store/counterSlice';

export default function CompB() {
  const dispatch = useDispatch();
  return (
    <div>
      <h2>CompB - Controls</h2>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch(increment())}>‚ûï Increment</button>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch(decrement())}>‚ûñ Decrement</button>
    </div>
  );
}

    8. app/components/CompC.js

    
'use client';
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { reset } from '../../store/counterSlice';

export default function CompC() {
  const dispatch = useDispatch();
  return (
    <div>
      <h2>CompC - Reset</h2>
      <button onClick={() => dispatch(reset())}>üîÑ Reset</button>
    </div>
  );
}

    9. Dependencies in package.json

    
{
  "dependencies": {
    "next": "13.5.0",
    "react": "18.2.0",
    "react-dom": "18.2.0",
    "@reduxjs/toolkit": "^1.9.5",
    "react-redux": "^8.1.2"
  }
}

    Run the App:

    
npx create-next-app@latest redux-nextjs-app-router --app
cd redux-nextjs-app-router
# Replace files with the above code
npm install
npm run dev
  • What is Redux Toolkit?

    Redux Toolkit (RTK) is the official, recommended way to write Redux logic. It provides a set of tools and abstractions to simplify Redux development and eliminate boilerplate code.

    üîß Features:

    • createSlice: Combines reducers and actions into a single slice.
    • configureStore: Sets up the Redux store with sensible defaults like middleware and DevTools support.
    • createAsyncThunk: Simplifies async logic and data fetching (e.g. API calls).
    • createReducer: Reduces boilerplate when writing reducers with immutability handled internally.
    • Immer.js integration: Allows writing ‚Äúmutating‚Äù code that is internally converted to immutable updates.

    ‚úÖ Benefits:

    • Less boilerplate code
    • Built-in DevTools setup
    • Standardized Redux patterns
    • Improved developer experience

    üì¶ Example:

    // counterSlice.js
import { createSlice } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';

const counterSlice = createSlice({
  name: 'counter',
  initialState: { value: 0 },
  reducers: {
    increment: state => { state.value += 1 },
    decrement: state => { state.value -= 1 },
    reset: state => { state.value = 0 },
  }
});

export const { increment, decrement, reset } = counterSlice.actions;
export default counterSlice.reducer;

    Use this slice in your Redux configureStore():

    // store.js
import { configureStore } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
import counterReducer from './counterSlice';

export const store = configureStore({
  reducer: {
    counter: counterReducer,
  }
});

    üìö Documentation:

    https://redux-toolkit.js.org
  • Redux vs Redux Toolkit

    Redux is a state management library, and Redux Toolkit (RTK) is the official, recommended way to use Redux efficiently.

    üîç Comparison:

    Feature Redux Redux Toolkit (RTK)
    Boilerplate Verbose and repetitive code Minimal code using helpers like createSlice
    Setup Manual store, middleware, DevTools setup configureStore auto-configures everything
    Reducers Written manually with switch-case Created using createSlice and Immer
    Async Actions Manual thunk creation and boilerplate createAsyncThunk simplifies async logic
    Best Practices Optional Built-in by design
    Learning Curve Steeper Beginner-friendly

    ‚úÖ Conclusion:

    • Redux: Good for learning concepts, but verbose and error-prone.
    • Redux Toolkit: The modern, recommended way to write Redux apps with less code and better defaults.

    üìò Official Docs:

    • https://redux.js.org (Redux)
    • https://redux-toolkit.js.org (Redux Toolkit)
  • React + Redux Toolkit Example with CompA, CompB, CompC 
    Folder Structure:
react-redux-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompA.js
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompB.js
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CompC.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ redux/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ store.js
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ counterSlice.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json

    1. src/redux/counterSlice.js
import { createSlice } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';

const counterSlice = createSlice({
name: 'counter',
initialState: { value: 0 },
reducers: {
increment: (state) => { state.value += 1 },
decrement: (state) => { state.value -= 1 },
reset: (state) => { state.value = 0 }
},
});

export const { increment, decrement, reset } = counterSlice.actions;
export default counterSlice.reducer;

    2. src/redux/store.js
import { configureStore } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
import counterReducer from './counterSlice';

export const store = configureStore({
reducer: {
counter: counterReducer,
},
});

    3. src/components/CompA.js
import { useSelector } from 'react-redux';

export default function CompA() {
const count = useSelector((state) => state.counter.value);
return (
<div>
<h2>CompA</h2>
<p>Counter Value: {count}</p>
</div>
);
}

    4. src/components/CompB.js
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { increment, decrement } from '../redux/counterSlice';

export default function CompB() {
const dispatch = useDispatch();
return (
<div>
<h2>CompB</h2>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(increment())}>‚ûï Increment</button>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(decrement())}>‚ûñ Decrement</button>
</div>
);
}

    5. src/components/CompC.js
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { reset } from '../redux/counterSlice';

export default function CompC() {
const dispatch = useDispatch();
return (
<div>
<h2>CompC</h2>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(reset())}>üîÑ Reset</button>
</div>
);
}

    6. src/App.js
import CompA from './components/CompA';
import CompB from './components/CompB';
import CompC from './components/CompC';

function App() {
return (
<div style={{ padding: 20 }}>
<h1>React + Redux Toolkit Example</h1>
<CompA />
<CompB />
<CompC />
</div>
);
}

export default App;

    7. src/index.js
import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import App from './App';
import { Provider } from 'react-redux';
import { store } from './redux/store';

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(
<Provider store={store}>
<App />
</Provider>
);

}

  • React + Redux (Classic) Example with CompA, CompB, CompC 
    üìÅ Folder Structure:
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompA.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompB.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CompC.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ redux/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ reducer.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ store.js

    1Ô∏è‚É£ redux/actions.js
export const increment = () => ({ type: 'INCREMENT' });
export const decrement = () => ({ type: 'DECREMENT' });
export const reset = () => ({ type: 'RESET' });

    2Ô∏è‚É£ redux/reducer.js
const initialState = { value: 0 };

export const counterReducer = (state = initialState, action) => {
switch (action.type) {
case 'INCREMENT':
return { value: state.value + 1 };
case 'DECREMENT':
return { value: state.value - 1 };
case 'RESET':
return { value: 0 };
default:
return state;
}
};

    3Ô∏è‚É£ redux/store.js
import { createStore } from 'redux';
import { counterReducer } from './reducer';

export const store = createStore(counterReducer);

    4Ô∏è‚É£ components/CompA.js
import { useSelector } from 'react-redux';

export default function CompA() {
const count = useSelector((state) => state.value);
return (
<div>
<h2>CompA</h2>
<p>Counter: {count}</p>
</div>
);
}

    5Ô∏è‚É£ components/CompB.js
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { increment, decrement } from '../redux/actions';

export default function CompB() {
const dispatch = useDispatch();
return (
<div>
<h2>CompB</h2>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(increment())}>‚ûï Increment</button>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(decrement())}>‚ûñ Decrement</button>
</div>
);
}

    6Ô∏è‚É£ components/CompC.js
import { useDispatch } from 'react-redux';
import { reset } from '../redux/actions';

export default function CompC() {
const dispatch = useDispatch();
return (
<div>
<h2>CompC</h2>
<button onClick={() => dispatch(reset())}>üîÑ Reset</button>
</div>
);
}

    7Ô∏è‚É£ App.js
import CompA from './components/CompA';
import CompB from './components/CompB';
import CompC from './components/CompC';

function App() {
return (
<div style={{ padding: 20 }}>
<h1>React + Redux Example</h1>
<CompA />
<CompB />
<CompC />
</div>
);
}

export default App;

    8Ô∏è‚É£ index.js

import { store } from './redux/store';

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(
<Provider store={store}>
<App />
</Provider>
);

  • Zustand + Next.js App Router with CompA, CompB, CompC 
    üìÅ Folder Structure (app router):
app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ page.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompA.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompB.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CompC.js
store/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ useCounterStore.js

    1Ô∏è‚É£ store/useCounterStore.js

'use client';
import { create } from 'zustand';

export const useCounterStore = create((set) => ({
count: 0,
increment: () => set((state) => ({ count: state.count + 1 })),
decrement: () => set((state) => ({ count: state.count - 1 })),
reset: () => set({ count: 0 }),
}));

    2Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompA.js      
'use client';
import { useCounterStore } from '../../store/useCounterStore';

export default function CompA() {
const count = useCounterStore((state) => state.count);

return (
<div>
<h2>CompA</h2>
<p>Counter: {count}</p>
</div>
);
}

    3Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompB.js
'use client';
import { useCounterStore } from '../../store/useCounterStore';

export default function CompB() {
const increment = useCounterStore((state) => state.increment);
const decrement = useCounterStore((state) => state.decrement);

return (
<div>
<h2>CompB</h2>
<button onClick={increment}>‚ûï Increment</button>
<button onClick={decrement}>‚ûñ Decrement</button>
</div>
);
}

    4Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompC.js      
'use client';
import { useCounterStore } from '../../store/useCounterStore';

export default function CompC() {
const reset = useCounterStore((state) => state.reset);

return (
<div>
<h2>CompC</h2>
<button onClick={reset}>üîÑ Reset</button>
</div>
);
}

          
5Ô∏è‚É£ app/page.js
import CompA from './components/CompA';
import CompB from './components/CompB';
import CompC from './components/CompC';

export default function HomePage() {
return (
<main style={{ padding: 20 }}>
<h1>Zustand + Next.js Example</h1>
<CompA />
<CompB />
<CompC />
</main>
);
}

}
}

npm install zustand
# Replace files with the code above
