  • Context API + Next.js App Router with CompA, CompB, CompC 
    üìÅ Folder Structure (App Router)
app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ page.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ context/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CounterContext.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompA.js
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CompB.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CompC.js

    1Ô∏è‚É£ app/context/CounterContext.js

'use client';
import { createContext, useContext, useState } from 'react';

const CounterContext = createContext();
export const useCounter = () => useContext(CounterContext);

export function CounterProvider({ children }) {
const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

const increment = () => setCount((c) => c + 1);
const decrement = () => setCount((c) => c - 1);
const reset = () => setCount(0);

return (
<CounterContext.Provider value={{ count, increment, decrement, reset }}>
{children}
</CounterContext.Provider>
);
}

    2Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompA.js

'use client';
import { useCounter } from '../context/CounterContext';

export default function CompA() {
const { count } = useCounter();

return (
<div>
<h2>CompA</h2>
<p>Counter: {count}</p>
</div>
);
}

    3Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompB.js

'use client';
import { useCounter } from '../context/CounterContext';

export default function CompB() {
const { increment, decrement } = useCounter();

return (
<div>
<h2>CompB</h2>
<button onClick={increment}>‚ûï Increment</button>
<button onClick={decrement}>‚ûñ Decrement</button>
</div>
);
}

    4Ô∏è‚É£ app/components/CompC.js
'use client';
import { useCounter } from '../context/CounterContext';

export default function CompC() {
const { reset } = useCounter();

return (
<div>
<h2>CompC</h2>
<button onClick={reset}>üîÑ Reset</button>
</div>
);
}

    5Ô∏è‚É£ app/page.js
'use client';
import { CounterProvider } from './context/CounterContext';
import CompA from './components/CompA';
import CompB from './components/CompB';
import CompC from './components/CompC';

export default function HomePage() {
return (
<CounterProvider>
<main style={{ padding: 20 }}>
  <h1>Context API + Next.js Example</h1>
  <CompA />
  <CompB />
  <CompC />
</main>
</CounterProvider>
);
}

          
üì¶ package.json dependencies
{
"dependencies": {
"next": "^14.0.0",
"react": "^18.2.0",
"react-dom": "^18.2.0"
}
}

    üöÄ Run Instructions      
npx create-next-app@latest context-next-app --app --ts --no-tailwind
cd context-next-app
# Replace files as per structure above
npm run dev
  • What happens if we don't use Redux Thunk to call an API?

    üö´ Without Redux Thunk (or middleware):

    Redux only supports synchronous actions by default. This means:

    • You can only dispatch plain JavaScript objects ‚Äî not functions or Promises.
    • If you try to dispatch an async function (like a fetch call), Redux will throw an error because it doesn't know how to handle it.

    üß™ Example (Invalid without Thunk):

    
// ‚ùå This won't work without Redux Thunk
dispatch(async (dispatch) => {
const response = await fetch('/api/data');
const data = await response.json();
dispatch({ type: 'SET_DATA', payload: data });
});

    Redux will throw: Actions must be plain objects. Use custom middleware for async actions.

    ‚úÖ What Redux Thunk Enables:

    • Lets you return functions (not just plain objects) from your action creators.
    • Allows you to delay the dispatch of an action, or to dispatch only if a certain condition is met.
    • Gives access to dispatch and getState inside the thunk.

    üõ†Ô∏è Alternative Solutions:

    • Redux Toolkit Query (RTK Query) ‚Äì Modern approach, handles API requests and caching.
    • Redux Saga ‚Äì Generator-based middleware for complex flows.
    • Use useEffect + Context or Zustand ‚Äì Simpler state management without Redux at all.

    üìù Summary:

    • Redux cannot handle async logic on its own.
    • Using Redux Thunk or other middleware is essential if you want to perform side effects like API calls in Redux actions.
  • What is the difference between process.nextTick() and setImmediate() in Node.js?

    üîç Summary:

    • process.nextTick() queues a callback to be invoked immediately after the current operation, before any I/O or timers.
    • setImmediate() queues a callback to be run on the next iteration of the event loop, after I/O events.

    üìå Execution Order Example:

    
console.log('Start');

process.nextTick(() => {
console.log('nextTick callback');
});

setImmediate(() => {
console.log('setImmediate callback');
});

console.log('End');

    üßæ Output:

    
Start
End
nextTick callback
setImmediate callback

    üìò Explanation:

    • process.nextTick() callbacks are executed after the current function but before the event loop continues.
    • setImmediate() callbacks are scheduled to run on the next tick of the event loop, after I/O events like timers or network requests.

    ‚õî Warning:

    Overusing process.nextTick() (e.g., recursively) can block the event loop and cause starvation of I/O operations.

    ‚úÖ Use When:

    • Use process.nextTick() to delay execution until after the current function but before I/O.
    • Use setImmediate() when you want to execute code after I/O events or to yield the event loop.
  • React.memo?
    React.memo is a higher-order component (HOC) in React that memoizes a functional component.
    It prevents unnecessary re-renders by caching the component‚Äôs output unless its props change. 
      const MyComponent = React.memo((props) => {
    // ...
  });

    React.memo can cause unnecessary complexity, stale UI bugs due to shallow prop comparison, and increased memory usage.
    It adds overhead if the component is simple or props don‚Äôt change often.

    Overusing it without profiling may degrade performance rather than improve it, especially in large or dynamic component trees.


    • Extra work on every render due to shallow comparison
    • False sense of performance improvement
    • Stale or mutated props causing bugs
    • Over-optimizing the wrong layer
    • Blocks intentional re-renders (e.g., animations)
    • Increased memory overhead
    • Hurts concurrent rendering in React 18
    • Makes debugging more difficult
  • How does lifting state up work
    Lifting state up is a fundamental concept in React where you move state to the closest common ancestor of components that need to share or coordinate data. This allows the shared state to be passed down as props, ensuring that all components stay in sync when the state changes.
  • Map vs Set
    const arr = [1, 2, 2, 3];
    const unique = [...new Set(arr)];
    console.log(unique); // [1, 2, 3]
    Feature Map Set
    Purpose Stores key-value pairs Stores unique values
    Key uniqueness Keys must be unique All values must be unique
    Key types Can be of any type (object, function, etc.) Not applicable (values only)
    Value access Via map.get(key) No direct access, use iteration
    Insertion order Maintains insertion order Maintains insertion order
    Duplicates allowed No duplicate keys No duplicate values
    Use cases When you need key-value lookups When you need a collection of unique items
  • Reconciliation?
    Reconciliation is the process React uses to update the DOM efficiently when the state or props of a component change. Instead of re-rendering the entire UI, React:
    1. Uses the Virtual DOM to represent the current state of the UI.
    2. Compares the new Virtual DOM with the previous one using a diffing algorithm.
    3. Calculates the minimal number of changes needed.
    4. Updates only the changed parts in the real DOM.
    Example: If only one item in a list changes, React will update that item instead of re-rendering the entire list.
    Benefits: - Improves performance. - Avoids full page refresh. - Provides smooth user experiences by minimizing DOM operations. This efficient update process is what makes React fast and responsive.
  • React?
    1. React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces, especially for single-page applications. It allows developers to create reusable UI components.
    2. Components are the building blocks of a React application. They can be functional or class-based, and each component represents a part of the UI.
    3. JSX (JavaScript XML) is a syntax extension that allows writing HTML inside JavaScript. It makes the code more readable and easier to write React elements.
    4. Reconciliation React compares the new virtual DOM with the previous one using a diffing algorithm and updates only the parts of the DOM that changed (this process is called reconciliation).
    5. Controlled Components : form elements whose values are controlled by React state.
    6. Uncontrolled components : form elements that maintain their state using the DOM (accessed via refs).
    7. useState() : The useState() hook is used in React functional components to manage local state. It allows you to store, read, and update values across re-renders.
      This enables your component to reactively update the UI based on user interactions or other changes.
    8. Prop Drilling : Prop Drilling refers to the process of passing data from a parent component down to child components, and then further down to deeply nested components, even if intermediate components don‚Äôt need that data. It becomes problematic when the component tree is large, leading to tight coupling and making components harder to manage and maintain.
    9. defaultProps : is a feature in React that allows you to define default values for a component‚Äôs props. If a parent component does not provide a specific prop, the default value will be used instead. It helps prevent bugs and ensures components behave as expected even if some props are not passed.
      Usage (for functional components):
      
    const Greeting = ({ name = "Guest" }) => (
    <h1>Hello, {name}</h1>
    );
  • Commonly used hooks..
    1. useState
    2. useEffect runs after painting the DOM.
    3. useContext
    4. useReducer
    5. useCallback : Returns a memoized version of a function that only changes if dependencies change ‚Äî useful for preventing unnecessary re-renders.
    6. useMemo : memoizes the result of a function to avoid recalculating it. Memoizes a computed value, recalculating it only when dependencies change.
    7. useReducer : An alternative to useState for managing complex state logic.
    8. useRef :
    9. useLayoutEffect : runs synchronously before the DOM is painted ‚Äî useful for layout measurements or DOM mutations.
    10. useImperativeHandle
    11. useDebugValue
  • useReducer Example. 
      üîß üß™ Counter Component
  import React, { useReducer } from 'react';
  const initialState = { count: 0 };
  
  function myreducer(state, action) {
    switch (action.type) {
      case 'increment':
        return { count: state.count + 1 };
      case 'decrement':
        return { count: state.count - 1 };
      case 'reset':
        return initialState;
      default:
        throw new Error('Unknown action type');
    }
  }
  
  function Counter() {
    const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(myreducer, initialState);
  
    return (
      <div>
        <h2>Count: {state.count}</h2>
        <button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: 'decrement' })}>-</button>
        <button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: 'reset' })}>Reset</button>
        <button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: 'increment' })}>+</button>
      </div>
    );
  }

  export default Counter;

      üß† Explanation
  1. useReducer(reducer, initialState): Initializes state and gives you a dispatch method.
  2. reducer: A pure function to calculate new state based on the action type.
  3. dispatch({ type: 'increment' }): Triggers a state update through the reducer.

  ‚úÖ When to Use useReducer
  1. For complex state logic (e.g., multiple related values)
  2. When state changes are triggered by many different actions
  3. When the same logic must be reused across components
  • HOC?
    A Higher-Order Component (HOC) is an advanced pattern in React used to reuse component logic. It‚Äôs a function that takes a component and returns a new component with added functionality.

    Syntax:
    
    const withExtraProps = (WrappedComponent) => {
    return (props) => <WrappedComponent {...props} extra="value" />;
    };

    Use Cases:
    • Authentication
    • Logging
    • Theming or Localization
    • Permission Checks

    Example:
    
    const withLogger = (WrappedComponent) => {
    return (props) => {
    console.log('Props:', props);
    return <WrappedComponent {...props} />;
    };
    };
    
    const MyComponent = (props) => <div>{props.message}</div>;
    
    export default withLogger(MyComponent);

    Main Use:
    To reuse logic across multiple components without duplicating code.

    HOC vs Alternatives:
    • HOC: Wraps and returns enhanced component.
    • Render Props: Uses a function to determine what to render.
    • Custom Hooks: Encapsulates reusable logic using useXYZ.
  • Component Lifecycle
    React class components have 3 main lifecycle phases:
    1. Mounting (Component is being created and inserted into the DOM)
    2. Updating (Component is re-rendered due to prop or state changes)
    3. Unmounting (Component is removed from the DOM

  • React Vs ReactDOM?
    React and ReactDOM are two separate libraries in the React ecosystem, each with a distinct purpose:

    React : - React is the core library for building component-based user interfaces. - It provides methods like React.createElement(), useState(), and useEffect() for component logic. - It‚Äôs platform-agnostic, meaning it doesn‚Äôt assume the environment (browser, mobile, etc.).

    ReactDOM : - ReactDOM is the library that specifically handles rendering React components to the DOM (i.e., web browsers). - It includes methods like ReactDOM.createRoot() and ReactDOM.render(). - It bridges React with the actual DOM for web applications.

    In Summary:
    - Use React for building components and managing logic. - Use ReactDOM for mounting React components to the web page.
  • How can you improve performance in a React application?
    Improving performance in a React application involves multiple strategies to minimize re-renders, optimize rendering behavior, and reduce resource usage.

    Key Techniques:
    1. Memoization: Use React.memo for components and useMemo for values to avoid unnecessary recalculations.
    2. useCallback: Prevents re-creation of functions during re-renders.
    3. Code Splitting: Use React.lazy and Suspense to load components on demand.
    4. Virtualization: Libraries like react-window or react-virtualized render only visible items in long lists.
    5. Efficient State Management: Keep state local where possible and avoid lifting state unnecessarily.
    6. Avoid Inline Functions: Especially in props of frequently updating components.
    7. Debounce Input Handlers: Reduces update frequency in response to user typing or scroll events.
    8. Use Production Builds: Always deploy with optimized production build using npm run build.

    Tools: Use tools like React DevTools, Lighthouse, and Chrome Performance tab to identify performance bottlenecks.
  • ReactJS UI Developer Interview Questions (10+ Years Experience)

    üß† React Core Concepts (Advanced)

    1. Explain the concept of React Fiber architecture. How does it differ from the previous reconciliation algorithm?
    2. What are the phases of the React rendering lifecycle in class and functional components?
    3. Explain the purpose of keys in React. What are the risks of using indexes as keys?
    4. How does React batch updates and how does it impact performance?
    5. Describe controlled vs uncontrolled components with examples.
    6. How does reconciliation work in React?
    7. What is StrictMode in React and how does it help in development?
    8. How do error boundaries work? Can you implement a reusable one?

    ‚öôÔ∏è Hooks & Custom Hooks

    1. Difference between useEffect, useLayoutEffect, and useInsertionEffect.
    2. Explain how stale closures can affect useEffect or useCallback.
    3. What are the rules of hooks? How does React enforce them?
    4. Build a custom hook for data fetching with loading and error state.
    5. What is useRef used for? Give examples of DOM access and persistent value storage.
    6. Compare useMemo and useCallback. When should each be used?

    üì¶ State Management

    1. When to choose Redux over Context API?
    2. How do you structure a Redux Toolkit application?
    3. What are the performance issues with Context API and how to resolve them?
    4. How to manage cross-component state sharing using hooks and context?
    5. Compare Redux with Recoil, Zustand, and Jotai.

    üìê Architecture & Design Patterns

    1. How do you structure a large-scale React app for maintainability and scalability?
    2. Explain the compound component pattern in React.
    3. Describe the container/presenter (smart/dumb) component pattern.
    4. What is the render props pattern? Why is it less used today?
    5. How do you implement feature flags in a React application?
    6. Explain code splitting and lazy loading in React.

    üé® UI/UX & Performance Optimization

    1. How do you improve React app performance?
    2. What are common anti-patterns in React UI development?
    3. How would you handle infinite scrolling or virtualized lists in React?
    4. How do you optimize for First Contentful Paint (FCP) in SPAs?
    5. Discuss debounce vs throttle in input optimization.

    üß™ Testing & CI/CD

    1. How do you write tests for hooks using React Testing Library?
    2. What are strategies to test components with asynchronous behavior?
    3. How do you perform snapshot testing? What are its limitations?
    4. Difference between unit, integration, and E2E testing in React context?
    5. How do you set up CI for React testing with GitHub Actions or GitLab CI?

    üîå API Integration & Side Effects

    1. How do you manage side effects in React applications?
    2. How do you cancel an API request in a component?
    3. What strategies do you use for retrying failed requests?
    4. How do you build loading indicators, skeleton loaders, and optimistic UIs?
    5. How do you implement a debounced search input with API calls?

    üåê Accessibility & Internationalization

    1. How do you ensure accessibility (a11y) in your components?
    2. How do you implement RTL (right-to-left) support?
    3. How do you implement i18n (internationalization) in React?

    üõ† Tooling, Libraries & Ecosystem

    1. Why choose Vite or Turbopack over CRA?
    2. How do you configure ESLint, Prettier, and Husky?
    3. How do you handle responsive design and browser compatibility?
    4. How do you implement theming and dark/light modes?
    5. Which UI libraries (e.g. MUI, Tailwind) do you prefer and why?

    üíº Behavioral & System Design (Frontend)

    1. How do you prioritize UI tasks under tight deadlines?
    2. Describe a time when you solved a critical performance issue.
    3. How would you design a real-time dashboard in React?
    4. How do you structure a multi-step form wizard?
    5. How would you handle multi-theme, multi-locale, PWA-ready UI requirements?
  • When to Choose Redux Over Context API?
    • Global State Complexity: If your application has complex state logic involving deeply nested structures, multiple reducers, or cross-slice interactions, Redux is better suited with its middleware and action-based architecture.
    • Predictable State Management: Redux enforces a strict unidirectional data flow and immutability, making debugging and state tracking easier, especially using tools like Redux DevTools.
    • Performance Optimization: Context API can cause unnecessary re-renders when the provider value changes. Redux, with its connect HOC or useSelector hook, allows fine-grained component subscription, minimizing re-renders.
    • Middleware Support: Redux offers middleware (like Redux Thunk, Redux Saga) for handling async logic, logging, caching, and side effects in a structured and scalable way.
    • Code Scalability: For large applications with teams working on different modules, Redux's organized file structure (actions, reducers, selectors) makes the state management easier to scale and maintain.
    • Third-party Ecosystem: Redux has a rich ecosystem of developer tools, middleware, and community support, which can save development time and improve reliability.
    • Time Travel Debugging: Redux supports advanced debugging features such as time-travel debugging which is not possible with Context API alone.

    Use Context API When:

    • Your state is not deeply nested or too complex.
    • You are managing UI-level state like themes, user preferences, or modals.
    • You want to avoid boilerplate and keep the project lightweight.
  • ---------------------------------------
    ---------------------------------------
  • useCallback() help performance?
    useCallback() is a React hook that memoizes a function, preventing it from being re-created on every render unless its dependencies change. This improves performance, especially when passing callback functions to memoized child components, because it avoids unnecessary re-renders.
    Use Case: When a child component receives a function as a prop and is wrapped with React.memo, using useCallback ensures that the function reference remains stable. Example: 
    
    const handleClick = useCallback(() => {
    console.log('Button clicked');
    }, []);
    This helps reduce render cycles and optimize React apps by maintaining stable function references.
  • useCallback() : Example
    Here's a basic and easy-to-understand example of how useCallback() avoids unnecessary re-renders. 
    
    // Parent.jsx
    import React, { useState, useCallback } from 'react';
    import Button from './Button';
    
    const Parent = () => {
    const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
    
    const sayHello = useCallback(() => {
    alert("Hello!");
    }, []);
    
    return (
    <div>
    <p>Count: {count}</p>
    <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Increment</button>
    <Button onClick={sayHello} />
    </div>
    );
    };
    
    export default Parent;
    
    // Button.jsx
    import React from 'react';
    
    const Button = React.memo(({ onClick }) => {
    console.log("Button rendered");
    return <button onClick={onClick}>Say Hello</button>;
    });
    
    export default Button;
    Explanation: Each time the count updates, Parent re-renders. Without useCallback, a new sayHello function would be created each time, causing Button to re-render too. With useCallback, the function reference stays the same, preventing the Button from unnecessary re-renders.
  • What is the second parameter [] in useCallback(fn, [])?
    The second parameter in useCallback(() => {...}, []) is called the dependency array. - An empty array [] means the callback function will be created once on the initial render and reused on every re-render. - If any dependencies are listed inside the array (e.g., [count]), the function will only be re-created if those dependencies change. Example: 
    
    const sayHello = useCallback(() => {
    alert("Hello!");
    }, []); // No dependencies ‚Äì function never re-created
    Purpose: Improves performance by avoiding unnecessary re-creation of functions unless specific values change.
  • useCallback() : Example 02
    Here‚Äôs a practical example of how useCallback() helps prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components that depend on callback props. 
    
    // ParentComponent.jsx
    import React, { useState, useCallback } from 'react';
    import Child from './Child';
    
    const Parent = () => {
    const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
    
    const handleClick = useCallback(() => {
    console.log('Clicked!');
    }, []);
    
    return (
    <div>
    <h2>Count: {count}</h2>
    <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Increment</button>
    <Child onClick={handleClick} />
    </div>
    );
    };
    
    export default Parent;
    
    // Child.jsx
    import React from 'react';
    
    const Child = React.memo(({ onClick }) => {
    console.log('Child rendered');
    return <button onClick={onClick}>Child Button</button>;
    });
    
    export default Child;
    Why this improves performance:
    Without useCallback(), the handleClick function gets re-created on each render, causing Child to re-render too. With useCallback(), the function is memoized and doesn‚Äôt change unless its dependencies change, preventing unnecessary renders.
  • ---------------------------------------
    ---------------------------------------
  • Memory Cleanup
    Memory cleanup in React refers to the practice of releasing resources, subscriptions, and side effects when a component unmounts or re-renders, to avoid memory leaks.

    Why it's important:
    • Prevents memory leaks.
    • Improves app performance and stability.
    • Avoids unwanted side effects.

    Typical use case with useEffect: 
    
    useEffect(() => {
    const id = setInterval(() => {
    console.log('Running interval...');
    }, 1000);
    
    return () => {
    clearInterval(id); // cleanup
    };
    }, []);

    Other cleanup examples:
    • WebSocket connections: Close them on unmount.
    • Event listeners: Remove them using removeEventListener.
    • Subscriptions: Unsubscribe to avoid multiple calls.

    Key Tip: Always return a cleanup function inside useEffect to handle teardown properly.

    Prevents memory leaks: Cleaning up resources like timers, listeners, or network requests ensures your app doesn‚Äôt hold onto unused memory, avoiding gradual slowdowns or crashes.
    Memory leaks happen when resources like timers or event listeners persist after a component unmounts, causing increased memory use over time.
    Example: Forgetting to clear a setInterval keeps it running even when the component is gone.

    Improves app performance and stability: Proper cleanup reduces unnecessary work and resource consumption, making your app faster and more reliable.
    Cleaning up avoids unnecessary processing and frees resources, helping the app run faster and reducing crashes.
    Example: Removing event listeners prevents them from firing needlessly.

    Avoids unwanted side effects: Stale or orphaned subscriptions can cause unexpected behavior; cleanup stops this by removing obsolete event handlers or data fetches. Side effects like duplicated API calls or event handling can cause bugs.
    Example: Multiple listeners causing repeated console logs.

    WebSocket connections: Close WebSocket connections on component unmount to prevent ongoing data streams and memory usage.

    Event listeners: Always remove event listeners with removeEventListener to avoid duplicated or lingering handlers.

    Proper cleanup ensures smooth, predictable app behavior and optimal resource use.
    WebSocket connections: Always close WebSockets on unmount to stop receiving messages and free resources.
    useEffect(() => {
    const ws = new WebSocket('wss://example.com');
    ws.onmessage = event => console.log(event.data);
    return () => ws.close();
    }, []);
    Event listeners: Add listeners on mount and remove on unmount.
    useEffect(() => {
    const onScroll = () => console.log('scroll');
    window.addEventListener('scroll', onScroll);
    return () => window.removeEventListener('scroll', onScroll);
    }, []);
    Subscriptions: Unsubscribe from observables or data sources to prevent multiple triggers and memory leaks. Unsubscribe to avoid multiple triggers.
    useEffect(() => {
    const subscription = someObservable.subscribe(data => console.log(data));
    return () => subscription.unsubscribe();
    }, []);
    Cleaning up keeps React apps efficient and bug-free.
  • Memory Cleanup : timers, listeners and network requests to prevent memory leaks
    Here‚Äôs a React example showing how to clean up timers, event listeners, and fetch requests: 
    import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';
    
    const CleanupExample = () => {
    const [data, setData] = useState(null);
    
    useEffect(() => {
    // Timer setup
    const timerId = setInterval(() => {
    console.log('Timer tick');
    }, 1000);
    
    // Event listener setup
    const handleResize = () => {
    console.log('Window resized');
    };
    window.addEventListener('resize', handleResize);
    
    // Network request with AbortController
    const controller = new AbortController();
    fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts/1', { signal: controller.signal })
    .then(res => res.json())
    .then(json => setData(json))
    .catch(err => {
    if (err.name === 'AbortError') {
    console.log('Fetch aborted');
    } else {
    console.error(err);
    }
    });
    
    // Cleanup function runs on component unmount
    return () => {
    clearInterval(timerId);             // Clear timer
    window.removeEventListener('resize', handleResize); // Remove listener
    controller.abort();                  // Abort fetch request
    console.log('Cleaned up resources');
    };
    }, []);
    
    return (
    <div>
    <h3>Data from API:</h3>
    <pre>{JSON.stringify(data, null, 2)}</pre>
    </div>
    );
    };
    
    export default CleanupExample;
    This prevents memory leaks by stopping timers, removing listeners, and aborting unfinished network requests when the component unmounts.
  • How to handle memory cleanup for an items list fetched from an API in React?
    When fetching and displaying an items list from an API, it‚Äôs important to clean up resources like ongoing requests or subscriptions to prevent memory leaks.

    Example using axios with cancellation: 
    
    import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';
    import axios from 'axios';
    
    const ItemList = () => {
    const [items, setItems] = useState([]);
    
    useEffect(() => {
    const source = axios.CancelToken.source();
    
    axios.get('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts', {
    cancelToken: source.token
    })
    .then(res => setItems(res.data))
    .catch(err => {
    if(axios.isCancel(err)) {
    console.log('Request canceled');
    } else {
    console.error(err);
    }
    });
    
    return () => {
    source.cancel('Component unmounted, request canceled');
    };
    }, []);
    
    return (
    <ul>
    {items.map(item => (
    <li key={item.id}>{item.title}</li>
    ))}
    </ul>
    );
    };
    
    export default ItemList;

    Key points:
    • Use axios.CancelToken to cancel API requests if the component unmounts.
    • This prevents setting state on unmounted components, avoiding memory leaks and warnings.
    • Always clean up subscriptions or listeners similarly in useEffect.
  • Is memory cleanup possible with fetch() in React? How to do it?
    Yes, memory cleanup with fetch() is possible by using the AbortController API to cancel ongoing requests when a component unmounts.

    Example: 
    
    import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';
    
    const ItemList = () => {
    const [items, setItems] = useState([]);
    
    useEffect(() => {
    const controller = new AbortController();
    const signal = controller.signal;
    
    fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts', { signal })
    .then(response => response.json())
    .then(data => setItems(data))
    .catch(err => {
    if (err.name === 'AbortError') {
    console.log('Fetch aborted');
    } else {
    console.error(err);
    }
    });
    
    return () => {
    controller.abort(); // Cleanup: abort fetch on unmount
    };
    }, []);
    
    return (
    <ul>
    {items.map(item => (
    <li key={item.id}>{item.title}</li>
    ))}
    </ul>
    );
    };
    
    export default ItemList;

    Summary:
    • AbortController cancels fetch requests.
    • Prevents setting state after unmount, avoiding memory leaks.
    • Works similarly to cancellation tokens in libraries like axios.
  • Lazy Loading
    Lazy loading in React is a performance optimization technique that delays the loading of components until they are needed. It reduces the initial bundle size and improves app load time. React provides: React.lazy() and Suspense for lazy loading components. Example: 
    
    // Lazy import
    const MyComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./MyComponent'));
    
    function App() {
    return (
    <Suspense fallback={<div>Loading...</div>}>
    <MyComponent />
    </Suspense>
    );
    }
    Key Benefits:
    • Faster initial load
    • Code splitting
    • Improved performance for large apps
  • Virtualization
    Virtualization in React refers to a performance optimization technique used to efficiently render long lists or large datasets by only rendering items visible in the viewport. Instead of rendering all items in the DOM, virtualization ensures that only a subset (visible + buffer) is rendered, improving load time and scroll performance.

    Popular Libraries:
    • react-window
    • react-virtualized

    Example: Instead of rendering 10,000 rows at once, virtualization renders only, say, 30 at a time, reusing DOM elements as the user scrolls.

    Benefits:
    • Improves rendering speed
    • Reduces memory usage
    • Enhances user experience with smooth scrolling

    Use Case: Ideal for chat apps, data grids, tables, and infinite scroll UIs.
  • How do you implement Virtualization with API data in a functional React component?
    You can combine virtualization with API data by first fetching data and then rendering it using a virtualization library like react-window.

    Step-by-step Example: 
    
    import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';
    import { FixedSizeList as List } from 'react-window';
    import axios from 'axios';
    
    const VirtualizedItemList = () => {
    const [items, setItems] = useState([]);
    
    useEffect(() => {
    axios.get('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts')
    .then((res) => setItems(res.data))
    .catch((err) => console.error(err));
    }, []);
    
    const Row = ({ index, style }) => (
    <div style={style}>
    <strong>{items[index]?.title}</strong>
    <p>{items[index]?.body}</p>
    </div>
    );
    
    return (
    <div>
    <h3>Virtualized API Item List</h3>
    {items.length > 0 && (
    <List
    height={400}
    itemCount={items.length}
    itemSize={80}
    width={'100%'}
    >
    {Row}
    </List>
    )}
    </div>
    );
    };
    
    export default VirtualizedItemList;

    Explanation:
    • axios fetches data from the API.
    • FixedSizeList renders only visible items.
    • Optimized for large lists with smooth scrolling.
  • ---------------------------------------
    ---------------------------------------
  • What is getDerivedStateFromProps in React?
    getDerivedStateFromProps is a static lifecycle method in React class components that gets called right before rendering, both on the initial mount and on subsequent updates. It is used to update the component's state based on changes in props.
    Syntax: 
    
    static getDerivedStateFromProps(nextProps, prevState) {
    if (nextProps.value !== prevState.value) {
    return { value: nextProps.value };
    }
    return null;
    }
    Use Cases:
    1. Sync internal state with props
    2. Reset state when props change
    Important Notes:
    1. It must return an object to update state or null to do nothing.
    2. Avoid side effects here‚Äîuse it only for state updates.
  • Difference between onChange and onInput?
    In React, both onChange and onInput are event handlers for form elements, but they behave slightly differently:
    onChange: - Triggered when the input loses focus or the value changes. - React wraps onChange to behave more like onInput (fires on every keystroke) for text inputs.
    onInput: - Triggered immediately after the value of an element changes. - Fires for more input types like range, color, etc.
    In practice: For text inputs, onChange and onInput behave similarly in React. 
    
    // Example
    <input onChange={(e) => console.log("Change:", e.target.value)} />
    <input onInput={(e) => console.log("Input:", e.target.value)} />
    Use onChange in React forms as it's the standard for capturing user input.


    When should we use onChange and when onInput in React? Use onChange when:
    1. You are working with form elements like <input>, <textarea>, or <select>.
    2. You want to follow React's controlled component pattern.
    3. You are managing form state (e.g., capturing user input in state).
    Use onInput when:
    1. You need more immediate, lower-level input events (e.g., for custom validation or live formatting).
    2. You're working with input types like range, color, or other non-text fields where onChange may behave differently.
    Example: 
    
    <!-- Standard form control -->
    <input type="text" onChange={(e) => setValue(e.target.value)} />
    
    <!-- Live input handling (e.g., formatting) -->
    <input type="text" onInput={(e) => handleFormat(e.target.value)} />
    In most React forms, onChange is the preferred and consistent choice.
  • What are Error Boundaries in React?
    Error Boundaries are React components that catch JavaScript errors anywhere in their child component tree, log those errors, and display a fallback UI instead of crashing the entire app.
    Use Case: They prevent an entire React app from crashing due to an error in a specific part of the UI.
    Implementing an Error Boundary: 
    
    class ErrorBoundary extends React.Component {
    constructor(props) {
    super(props);
    this.state = { hasError: false };
    }
    
    static getDerivedStateFromError(error) {
    return { hasError: true };
    }
    
    componentDidCatch(error, info) {
    console.error("Error caught:", error, info);
    }
    
    render() {
    if (this.state.hasError) {
    return <h1>Something went wrong.</h1>;
    }
    return this.props.children;
    }
    }
    Usage: 
    
    <ErrorBoundary>
    <MyComponent />
    </ErrorBoundary>
    Note: Error Boundaries only catch errors in render, lifecycle methods, and constructors of the child components‚Äînot in event handlers.
  • getStaticProps Vs getServerSideProps
    getStaticProps? Answer: Runs at build time to fetch data and pass it as props for static generation
    getServerSideProps? Answer: Runs on each request (server-side) to fetch data dynamically. 
      getStaticProps : 
  1. The API is called at build time.
  2. The fetched data is passed to the component as props.
  3. Since it‚Äôs static, the data will not change until you rebuild the app.
  4. The returned object must contain a props key.
  5. Ideal for static pages where data doesn't change often (e.g., blog, docs, home page).

  getServerSideProps : 
  1. It runs on every request, not at build time.
  2. Useful when data changes frequently or is user-specific.
  3. Good for authenticated pages or dashboards.


  const Home = ({ posts }) => {
      return (
        <>
          <h1>Blog Posts ( Static or Server-Side Rendered  )</h1>
          <ul>
            {posts.map((post) => (
              <span key={post.id}>
                {post.title}
              </span>
            ))}
            </ul>
          </>
      );
  }

  export async function getStaticProps / getServerSideProps () {

      const res = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts');
      const posts = await res.json();

      return {
        props: {
          posts: posts.slice(0, 5) // only the first 5 posts for brevity
        }
      };
  }
  
  export default Home;

    What is getStaticProps in Next.js?

    getStaticProps is a function in Next.js used for Static Site Generation (SSG). It allows you to fetch data at build time and pass it as props to your page component.

    When to use getStaticProps?

    • When you want to pre-render a page at build time.
    • When the data does not change frequently (like a blog or documentation).
    • For better performance as HTML is generated at build time.

    Example of getStaticProps

    Imagine you want to fetch and display a list of blog posts from an API during the build.

    File: pages/blog.js

    export async function getStaticProps() {
  const res = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts');
  const posts = await res.json();

  return {
    props: {
      posts,
    },
  };
}

function Blog({ posts }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>Blog Posts</h1>
      <ul>
        {posts.slice(0, 5).map((post) => (
          <li key={post.id}>
            <strong>{post.title}</strong><br />
            {post.body}
          </li>
        ))}
      </ul>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Blog;

    How it works?

    1. Next.js runs getStaticProps during the build process.
    2. The data is fetched and passed as props to the component.
    3. The HTML is generated at build time and served as static files.

    Benefits of getStaticProps

    • Fast page loads due to static HTML.
    • SEO-friendly content.
    • Reduced server load compared to SSR (Server-side rendering).

    What is getServerSideProps in Next.js?

    getServerSideProps is a function in Next.js used for Server-Side Rendering (SSR). It runs on the server on every request and fetches data which is passed to the page component as props.

    When to use getServerSideProps?

    • When the data needs to be fresh on every request (like user dashboards, live data).
    • When you need access to request-specific data (like headers, cookies, query params).
    • For dynamic content that changes frequently.

    Example of getServerSideProps

    Below is an example of a page that fetches user data from an API every time the page is requested.

    File: pages/user.js

    export async function getServerSideProps(context) {
  const res = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users/1');
  const user = await res.json();

  return {
    props: {
      user,
    },
  };
}

function User({ user }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>User Information</h1>
      <p><strong>Name:</strong> {user.name}</p>
      <p><strong>Email:</strong> {user.email}</p>
      <p><strong>Phone:</strong> {user.phone}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

export default User;

    How it works?

    1. When a request is made to the page, Next.js calls getServerSideProps on the server.
    2. The data is fetched on the server during the request.
    3. The data is sent as props to the React component and the HTML is generated and sent to the client.

    Benefits of getServerSideProps

    • Data is always up-to-date.
    • Great for pages that depend on request-specific data.
    • No need to manually call APIs on the client side.

    Drawbacks

    • Slower than static generation due to server-side computation on each request.
    • Increased server load under high traffic.
  • What is ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration)?
    Answer: Allows you to update static content after deployment without rebuilding the entire site. export async function getStaticProps() { return { props: { ... }, revalidate: 10, // seconds }; }
  • useImperativeHandle Hook

    üìå What is useImperativeHandle?

    useImperativeHandle is a React hook that lets you customize the instance value that is exposed when using ref with a functional component. It is commonly used with forwardRef.

    ‚úÖ Why Use It?

    • Expose only specific methods or values to parent components.
    • Hide internal component logic while allowing imperative access to a limited API.

    üß™ Syntax:

    
        useImperativeHandle(ref, () => ({
        // methods or properties to expose
        }));

    üß© Example:

    ChildComponent.js

    
        import React, { useImperativeHandle, useRef, forwardRef } from "react";
        
        const CustomInput = forwardRef((props, ref) => {
        const inputRef = useRef();
        
        useImperativeHandle(ref, () => ({
        focus: () => {
        inputRef.current.focus();
        },
        clear: () => {
        inputRef.current.value = "";
        }
        }));
        
        return <input ref={inputRef} type="text" />;
        });
        
        export default CustomInput;

    ParentComponent.js

    
        import React, { useRef } from "react";
        import CustomInput from "./CustomInput";
        
        function ParentComponent() {
        const inputRef = useRef();
        
        return (
        <div>
        <CustomInput ref={inputRef} />
        <button onClick={() => inputRef.current.focus()}>Focus</button>
        <button onClick={() => inputRef.current.clear()}>Clear</button>
        </div>
        );
        }

    üîç Summary:

    • useImperativeHandle helps define what a ref will expose to the parent.
    • Works only with forwardRef.
    • Useful when building reusable UI components like custom inputs, modals, or tooltips.
  • How do portals work in React?

    üìå What is a Portal?

    A portal allows you to render a child component into a different part of the DOM outside of its parent component hierarchy. This is useful for UI elements like modals, tooltips, and dropdowns that should visually break out of their container.

    ‚úÖ How It Works:

    React provides ReactDOM.createPortal(child, container) to render children into a DOM node that exists outside the DOM hierarchy of the parent component.

    üéØ Example:

    1. HTML structure (index.html):

    <body>
        <div id="root"></div>
        <div id="modal-root"></div>
        </body>

    2. React code:

    
        import React from "react";
        import ReactDOM from "react-dom";
        
        function Modal({ children }) {
        return ReactDOM.createPortal(
        <div className="modal">{children}</div>,
        document.getElementById("modal-root")
        );
        }
        
        function App() {
        return (
        <div>
        <h1>Main App</h1>
        <Modal>
        <p>This is rendered in a portal!</p>
        </Modal>
        </div>
        );
        }

    üîç Use Cases:

    • Modals and dialogs
    • Tooltips
    • Dropdowns
    • Floating notifications

    üöÄ Benefits:

    • Bypasses CSS overflow and z-index issues.
    • Makes it easier to manage UI elements that need to be rendered outside of parent containers.

    üß† Important Notes:

    • Although rendered outside the DOM tree, portals still behave as though they are inside the React tree (context and event bubbling still work).
  • What are render props and how are they different from HOCs?

    üìå Render Props:

    A render prop is a technique for sharing code between React components using a function prop that tells a component what to render.

    ‚úÖ Example:
    
        function DataProvider({ render }) {
        const data = { name: "React" };
        return render(data);
        }
        
        function App() {
        return (
        <DataProvider render={(data) => <h1>Hello {data.name}</h1>} />
        );
        }

    üìå Higher-Order Components (HOCs):

    An HOC is a function that takes a component and returns a new component with added behavior or props.

    ‚úÖ Example:
    
        function withUser(WrappedComponent) {
        return function EnhancedComponent(props) {
        const user = { name: "React" };
        return <WrappedComponent user={user} {...props} />;
        };
        }

    üîç Key Differences:

    Feature Render Props HOCs
    Code Sharing Via function prop Via component wrapping
    Flexibility More flexible control over rendering Less flexible, can cause wrapper nesting
    Component Tree Flatter hierarchy Can lead to wrapper hell
    Performance May cause inline function re-renders Can cause unnecessary re-renders without `React.memo`

    üöÄ Summary:

    • Render props pass a function to control rendering directly.
    • HOCs enhance components by wrapping them with extra logic or data.
    • Both help reuse component logic ‚Äî use whichever fits your use case better.
  • How does key prop affect reconciliation and re-rendering?

    The key prop in React is used to uniquely identify elements in a list. It helps React optimize rendering by efficiently determining which items have changed, been added, or removed during updates.

    üîç Why is key important?

    • React compares keys between renders to detect changes.
    • It prevents unnecessary re-renders by tracking which list items are stable.
    • Improves performance during reconciliation (the diffing process).

    ‚úÖ Correct Usage:

    
        const users = [{ id: 1, name: "Alice" }, { id: 2, name: "Bob" }];
        
        {users.map(user => (
        <div key={user.id}>{user.name}</div>
        ))}

    ‚ö†Ô∏è Avoid using array index as key when:

    • The list can change dynamically (add/remove/reorder).
    • Items have unique identifiers (like an id).

    üìå Example: Why a stable key matters

    Using an index as a key can cause React to incorrectly reuse DOM elements, leading to UI bugs.

    üöÄ Summary:

    • key is critical for efficient diffing in React‚Äôs Virtual DOM.
    • It ensures smooth and predictable UI updates.
    • Always use a unique, stable identifier (like database ID).
  • What is hydration in React and how does it work with SSR?

    Hydration in React is the process where the React application takes over a server-rendered HTML page and attaches event listeners to make it interactive. It's a crucial step in Server-Side Rendering (SSR) where the HTML is first rendered on the server and sent to the client.

    üß† How It Works:

    1. The server renders the HTML markup using React components.
    2. This static HTML is sent to the browser and displayed immediately.
    3. React on the client loads and uses the same component tree to "hydrate" or attach event handlers and state to the already-present DOM.

    ‚ö° Benefits:

    • Improves Time to First Paint (TTFP) by showing static content fast.
    • Enables SEO-friendly pages with full interactivity.

    ‚úÖ Example using hydrateRoot in React 18+

    
        // index.js
        import { hydrateRoot } from 'react-dom/client';
        import App from './App';
        
        hydrateRoot(document.getElementById('root'), <App />);

    In contrast to createRoot (used for CSR), hydrateRoot is specifically designed for hydrating HTML that was pre-rendered on the server.

    üìå Key Point:

    For hydration to work correctly, the server-rendered markup must exactly match what the client-side React expects. Mismatches will cause warnings and may break interactivity.

  • How do you optimize large lists in React applications?
    Rendering large lists in React can lead to performance issues due to the number of DOM nodes and frequent re-renders. Here are some common optimization techniques:
    • Windowing/Virtualization: Use libraries like react-window or react-virtualized to render only the visible portion of the list instead of the entire list at once. This reduces DOM nodes and improves performance.
    • Memoization: Use React.memo or useMemo to avoid unnecessary re-renders of list items when their props haven't changed.
    • Key Prop: Always provide a stable and unique key prop to list items to help React efficiently reconcile changes.
    • Lazy Loading: Load list data incrementally or on-demand rather than fetching and rendering all at once.
    • Avoid Inline Functions and Objects: Define functions and objects outside the render method or use useCallback and useMemo hooks to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
    • Pagination: Break down the large list into pages and render only the current page.

    Example using react-window:

    
        import { FixedSizeList as List } from 'react-window';
        
        function Row({ index, style }) {
        return <div style={style}>Item {index}</div>;
        }
        
        function MyList({ itemCount }) {
        return (
        <List
        height={500}
        itemCount={itemCount}
        itemSize={35}
        width={300}
        >
        {Row}
        </List>
        );
        }
  • Explain custom hooks: when and how to use them effectively.

    Custom hooks are JavaScript functions in React that start with the prefix use and can call other hooks (like useState, useEffect, etc.). They allow you to extract reusable, stateful logic from components so that it can be shared across multiple components easily.

    When to use custom hooks:

    • To share complex stateful logic between components without repeating code.
    • To abstract side effects such as fetching data, event listeners, or subscriptions.
    • To simplify component code by moving logic out into reusable functions.
    • To improve code organization and readability.

    How to use custom hooks effectively:

    1. Always name custom hooks with a use prefix to follow React conventions and enable lint rules.
    2. Keep hooks focused on a single responsibility or concern (e.g., data fetching, form handling, etc.).
    3. Return the minimal state and functions needed for the consuming components.
    4. Use built-in hooks inside your custom hook as needed (like useState, useEffect, useRef, etc.).
    5. Document what your hook does and what it returns for better maintainability.

    Example of a simple custom hook for window width tracking:

    
        import { useState, useEffect } from "react";
        
        function useWindowWidth() {
        const [width, setWidth] = useState(window.innerWidth);
        
        useEffect(() => {
        function handleResize() {
        setWidth(window.innerWidth);
        }
        
        window.addEventListener("resize", handleResize);
        
        // Cleanup the listener on unmount
        return () => {
        window.removeEventListener("resize", handleResize);
        };
        }, []);
        
        return width;
        }
        
        // Usage in a component
        function MyComponent() {
        const width = useWindowWidth();
        
        return <div>Window width is: {width}px</div>;
        }
  • How does React handle concurrent rendering?

    Concurrent Rendering is a set of new features in React that allows the library to interrupt and pause rendering work to keep the application responsive. Traditional React rendering is synchronous and blocking, meaning that once a rendering task starts, it must complete before the browser can perform other tasks like responding to user inputs or updating the UI.

    React‚Äôs Concurrent Rendering is a set of features that allows React to work on multiple tasks simultaneously by interrupting and pausing rendering work. Instead of blocking the main thread, React can split rendering into small units and spread them out over time, ensuring the app remains responsive to user input and other high-priority tasks.
    1. Interruptible Rendering: React can pause rendering work, handle more urgent updates like user input, then resume the rendering later.
    2. Prioritization: React assigns priorities to different updates, so critical updates like animations or typing are handled before less important ones.
    3. Smoother UI: By not blocking the main thread, apps feel faster and more fluid.
    4. Concurrent Mode: Enables React to prepare multiple versions of the UI simultaneously and switch between them seamlessly.
    This approach improves performance and user experience, especially in complex applications with heavy rendering.
  • What are Suspense and Concurrent Mode in React?

    Suspense: Used to display a fallback until its children have finished loading. This feature in React makes it easy to manage loading times in your components.
    Source: Angular Minds

    Concurrent Mode: A set of new features in React that allows the library to interrupt and pause rendering work to keep the application responsive.
    Source: Medium

    Suspense lets components "wait" for something before rendering. It is commonly used with lazy loading and data fetching. While waiting, React shows a fallback UI (like a loading spinner). 

    
        const LazyComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./MyComponent'));
        
        function App() {
        return (
        <Suspense fallback={'Loading...'}>
        <LazyComponent />
        </Suspense>
        );
        }

    Concurrent Mode is a set of features that allows React to interrupt, pause, and resume rendering. It helps React stay responsive by preparing multiple UI versions in the background.

    • Improves responsiveness and avoids UI jank.
    • Works well with Suspense for better async rendering.
    • Enabled via frameworks like Next.js or by using createRoot from react-dom.
    Summary:
    Suspense handles async rendering with fallbacks, and Concurrent Mode ensures rendering stays responsive by breaking work into small, interruptible units.
  • How would you build a hook for form validation?

    You can create a custom React hook to encapsulate form validation logic, which makes it reusable and keeps your components clean.

    üîß Step-by-step: useFormValidation Hook

    
        import { useState } from 'react';
        
        function useFormValidation(initialValues, validate) {
        const [values, setValues] = useState(initialValues);
        const [errors, setErrors] = useState({});
        
        const handleChange = (e) => {
        const { name, value } = e.target;
        setValues({ ...values, [name]: value });
        
        const validationErrors = validate({ ...values, [name]: value });
        setErrors(validationErrors);
        };
        
        const resetForm = () => {
        setValues(initialValues);
        setErrors({});
        };
        
        return {
        values,
        errors,
        handleChange,
        resetForm
        };
        }

    ‚úÖ Example Usage:

    
        function validate(values) {
        const errors = {};
        if (!values.email) {
        errors.email = "Email is required";
        } else if (!/\S+@\S+\.\S+/.test(values.email)) {
        errors.email = "Email is invalid";
        }
        return errors;
        }
        
        function MyForm() {
        const { values, errors, handleChange, resetForm } =
        useFormValidation({ email: '' }, validate);
        
        const handleSubmit = (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        if (Object.keys(errors).length === 0) {
        console.log("Form submitted:", values);
        resetForm();
        }
        };
        
        return (
        <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
        <input
        type="email"
        name="email"
        value={values.email}
        onChange={handleChange}
        />
        {errors.email && <p style={{ color: 'red' }}>{errors.email}</p>}
        <button type="submit">Submit</button>
        </form>
        );
        }

    üí° Benefits:

    • Reusable across multiple forms.
    • Keeps component clean and focused on rendering.
    • Flexible validation logic passed as a function.
  • Explain React‚Äôs Profiler API and how you use it to optimize performance.

    The React Profiler API is a tool that helps measure how often a component renders and the "cost" of rendering it. It‚Äôs useful for identifying performance bottlenecks in your React app.

    üß† Purpose:

    • Track component render frequency and duration.
    • Understand which components are re-rendering unnecessarily.
    • Guide optimizations using tools like React.memo, useMemo, and useCallback.

    üß™ Example usage:

    
        import { Profiler } from 'react';
        
        function onRenderCallback(
        id, // the "id" prop of the Profiler tree
        phase, // "mount" or "update"
        actualDuration, // time spent rendering
        baseDuration,
        startTime,
        commitTime,
        interactions
        ) {
        console.log({ id, phase, actualDuration });
        }
        
        function App() {
        return (
        <Profiler id="MyComponent" onRender={onRenderCallback}>
        <MyComponent />
        </Profiler>
        );
        }

    üìä Parameters Explained:

    • id: Identifier for the profiler.
    • phase: Whether it's a mount or update render.
    • actualDuration: Time taken to render.
    • baseDuration: Estimated time if no memoization is used.
    • startTime and commitTime: Timestamps of the render cycle.
    • interactions: The set of interactions that triggered the render.

    üöÄ How it helps optimization:

    • Helps pinpoint expensive renders.
    • Used in combination with DevTools and profiling tools.
    • Use the data to memoize components or split them into smaller parts.
  • How do you handle server-side rendering (SSR) in React?

    Server-Side Rendering (SSR) is the technique of rendering a React application on the server and sending the fully rendered HTML to the client. This improves performance and SEO by allowing search engines and users to see content faster.

    ‚úÖ Common Libraries and Frameworks for SSR:

    • Next.js ‚Äì Most popular React framework for SSR.
    • react-dom/server ‚Äì Low-level API used to manually implement SSR.

    üõ† Example using react-dom/server:

    
        import React from 'react';
        import ReactDOMServer from 'react-dom/server';
        import App from './App';
        
        const express = require('express');
        const app = express();
        
        app.get('*', (req, res) => {
        const html = ReactDOMServer.renderToString(<App />);
        res.send(`
        <!DOCTYPE html>
        <html>
        <head><title>SSR React</title></head>
        <body>
        <div id="root">${html}</div>
        <script src="/bundle.js"></script>
        </body>
        </html>
        `);
        });
        
        app.listen(3000);

    ‚öôÔ∏è How SSR Works:

    1. The server renders your React components to HTML.
    2. The HTML is sent to the browser and displayed instantly.
    3. React hydrates the HTML to make it interactive.
    üîç Benefits:
    • Faster first paint and improved SEO.
    • Better perceived performance on slow networks.
    üöß Caveats:
    • More server load and complexity.
    • Initial setup can be harder than client-side rendering (CSR).
  • What is hydration in React and how does it work with SSR?

    Hydration is the process of using client-side JavaScript to add application state and interactivity to server-rendered HTML.

    Sources: DEV Community, Gatsby, workingsoftware.dev

  • How does React batching work in modern React (18+)?

    Automatic batching in React means that multiple state updates triggered within the same event loop are batched together into a single render. In previous versions of React, only state updates within React event handlers were batched. With React 18, this batching behavior is extended to include all updates within the same event loop, including those from setTimeout, promises, native event handlers, and more.

    Sources: React, Medium, DEV Community

  • Explain custom hooks: when and how to use them effectively.

    Custom hooks are JavaScript functions that start with use and can call other hooks. They allow you to extract and reuse stateful logic across multiple components.

    When to use:

    • To share logic between components (e.g., form handling, fetching data).
    • To abstract complex logic into reusable functions.

    How to use:

    
        function useCustomHook() {
        const [state, setState] = useState(initialValue);
        // ...additional logic
        return [state, setState];
        }
  • What is memoization in React and when should you use React.memo?

    Memoization is an optimization technique to cache the result of expensive function calls. In React, React.memo is a higher-order component that prevents unnecessary re-renders by memoizing the result.

    Use React.memo when:

    • You have functional components that render the same output given the same props.
    • To prevent re-rendering unless props change.

    Example:

    
        const MemoizedComponent = React.memo(function MyComponent(props) {
        // render using props
        });
  • How does key prop affect reconciliation and re-rendering?

    The key prop helps React identify which items have changed, are added, or are removed. It should be a stable and unique identifier.

    Effects:

    • Improves performance by enabling efficient updates.
    • Prevents unnecessary re-renders.

    In React, the key prop is a special attribute used to uniquely identify elements in a list. It helps React efficiently update the UI by distinguishing which items have changed, been added, or removed.

    üîÑ How it affects reconciliation:

    • During reconciliation, React compares the new virtual DOM with the previous one.
    • If keys are consistent and unique, React can directly map and update only the changed components.
    • If keys are missing or reused incorrectly (like using array indices), React may unnecessarily re-render or remount items.

    ‚úÖ Best practices:

    • Use a unique and stable identifier from your data, like an id.
    • Avoid using array indexes as keys unless the list is static and won't change.

    üß™ Example:

    
        const items = [{ id: 1, name: 'Apple' }, { id: 2, name: 'Banana' }];
        return (
        <ul>
        {items.map(item => (
        <li key={item.id}>{item.name}</li>
        ))}
        </ul>
        );
    üöÄ Performance Impact:
    • Reduces unnecessary re-renders.
    • Improves performance by allowing React to reuse components intelligently.
  • How to create a custom input with middleware-like validation in React?

    You can build a custom input component in React that acts like a middleware by intercepting input changes, validating them, and then deciding whether to update the state or not.

    How It Works: CustomInput takes a middleware prop, a function that transforms or validates the input. On every input change, it applies the middleware to the raw input before calling onChange. In the example, numberOnlyMiddleware strips out all non-numeric characters.

    Why Use This Pattern? Reuse input logic like validation, formatting, or sanitization in multiple places. Separate concerns by isolating middleware logic from UI. Create flexible inputs that adapt behavior based on passed middleware.

    Example: Custom Input with Validation Middleware

    
          import React, { useState } from "react";
          
          function CustomInput({ value, onChange, validate }) {
            const handleChange = (e) => {
              const newValue = e.target.value;
          
              // Middleware validation step
              if (validate(newValue)) {
                onChange(newValue);
              } else {
                console.log("Validation failed:", newValue);
              }
            };
          
            return (
              <input
                type="text"
                value={value}
                onChange={handleChange}
                placeholder="Enter only letters"
              />
            );
          }
          
          function App() {
            const [text, setText] = useState("");
          
            // Validation middleware function: allow only letters
            const validateInput = (value) => /^[a-zA-Z]*$/.test(value);
          
            return (
              <div>
                <h3>Custom Input with Validation Middleware</h3>
                <CustomInput
                  value={text}
                  onChange={setText}
                  validate={validateInput}
                />
                <p>You typed: {text}</p>
              </div>
            );
          }
          
          export default App;

    Explanation:

    • CustomInput receives a validate function as a prop.
    • Inside handleChange, it runs the new input value through the validation function before calling onChange.
    • If validation fails, it blocks the update, mimicking middleware behavior.
    • This pattern allows adding validation, transformation, or side-effects before state update.
  • How does React Fiber work under the hood?
    React Fiber improves rendering performance, enables features like Suspense, Concurrent Mode, and better error handling.

    Key Concepts:
    1. Fiber Node: A JavaScript object representing a unit of work (component).
    2. Work Loop: React processes the fiber tree using a loop that can be paused and resumed, unlike the previous stack-based algorithm.
    3. Reconciliation: Fiber allows React to break down the rendering work into units and schedule them during idle time.
    4. Double Buffering: There are two fiber trees ‚Äî current and work-in-progress ‚Äî which help in comparing and updating only what's changed.
    How It Works:
    1. React builds a Fiber tree from the root component.
    2. It performs reconciliation to determine changes (diffing).
    3. Work is split into units and processed incrementally (time-slicing).
    4. React commits the final changes to the DOM in a separate phase.
    Benefits: Better scheduling, improved responsiveness, support for features like Suspense and Concurrent rendering.

    React Fiber enables React to handle complex UIs and asynchronous rendering more efficiently.
  • React Fiber: Example and Concept 
          React Fiber is the internal engine in React (since React 16+) that enables incremental rendering.
      It breaks the rendering work into units and spreads them over multiple frames,
      Allowing React to pause and resume work, handle priority updates, and make the app more responsive.
    
    üîç What it enables:
    1. Interruptible rendering
    2. Prioritized updates (e.g., user input over background tasks)
    3. Concurrency (via features like Suspense and startTransition)
    
    
    üß† Explanation:
    1. startTransition tells React that updating the large list is low-priority.
    2. User input (high-priority) is handled immediately.
    3. Thanks to React Fiber, rendering the long list can be paused and resumed, preventing UI blocking.
    
    This illustrates how Fiber supports concurrent rendering by allowing React to differentiate between urgent and non-urgent work.

    üì¶ Conceptual Example:

    
        // Simulating a high-priority user interaction vs low-priority background update
        
        import React, { useState, startTransition } from 'react';
        
        function FiberExample() {
          const [input, setInput] = useState('');
          const [list, setList] = useState([]);
        
          const handleChange = (e) => {
            const value = e.target.value;
            setInput(value);
        
            // Background update: non-blocking with startTransition
            startTransition(() => {
              const newList = Array(10000)
                .fill(0)
                .map((_, i) => `${value} - ${i}`);
              setList(newList);
            });
          };
        
          return (
            <div>
              <input type="text" value={input} onChange={handleChange} />
              <ul>
                {list.map((item, i) => <li key={i}>{item}</li>)}
              </ul>
            </div>
          );
        }
        
        export default FiberExample;
  • What is the difference between SSR and CSR in React?
    SSR (Server-Side Rendering): The HTML is rendered on the server and sent to the client. Faster first load, better SEO.
    CSR (Client-Side Rendering): The browser downloads JS and renders content dynamically. Faster interactions after load.
    Example: Next.js supports SSR; CRA (Create React App) uses CSR.
  • React Hooks Rules : eslint-plugin-react-hooks?
    • Only call hooks at the top level (not inside loops, conditions).
    • Only call hooks from React function components or custom hooks.
    • eslint-plugin-react-hooks to enforce rules.
  • What is Rehydration and How Does React Handle It?

    ‚úÖ Definition of Rehydration

    Rehydration is the process where React attaches event listeners and restores component state on the client side, using the static HTML sent from the server during Server-Side Rendering (SSR).

    üß† Why is Rehydration Important?

    • SSR sends pre-rendered HTML for faster initial load and SEO benefits.
    • After the browser loads the HTML, React hydrates it to make it interactive.
    • This allows users to see content immediately and interact without full re-render.

    ‚öôÔ∏è How React Handles Rehydration

    1. Uses hydrateRoot() (React 18+) or ReactDOM.hydrate() (React 17).
    2. Compares server-rendered HTML with virtual DOM.
    3. Attaches event listeners and internal React structures.
    4. Logs mismatches in development mode.

    üí° Code Example

    üëâ Server-side (e.g., Express or Next.js)

    import ReactDOMServer from 'react-dom/server';
        import App from './App';
        
        const html = ReactDOMServer.renderToString(<App />);

    üëâ Client-side

    import { hydrateRoot } from 'react-dom/client';
        import App from './App';
        
        const container = document.getElementById('root');
        hydrateRoot(container, <App />);

    üõë Pitfalls of Rehydration

    • Server and client render must match exactly.
    • Dynamic content like timestamps should be delayed until after hydration.

    üìå Summary Table

    Feature SSR Only SSR + Hydration
    Initial Load Fast Fast
    Interactivity ‚ùå None ‚úÖ Fully Interactive
    SEO Friendly ‚úÖ Yes ‚úÖ Yes
    Dynamic Behavior ‚ùå Not possible ‚úÖ After hydration
  • Trade-offs Between Redux and React Context

    üîç React Context

    React Context is designed for prop drilling avoidance, i.e., sharing data across deeply nested components (like theme, locale, or auth data).

    ‚úÖ Pros

    • Built into React ‚Äì no extra library needed.
    • Great for lightweight or static global state.
    • Easy to implement for small applications.

    ‚ùå Cons

    • Poor performance for high-frequency updates ‚Äî re-renders the whole subtree.
    • No dev tools like Redux for time-travel debugging.
    • No middleware support (like Redux Thunk, Saga).

    üß∞ Redux

    Redux is a powerful state management library designed to handle complex and large-scale state across your application.

    ‚úÖ Pros

    • Centralized state management.
    • Powerful developer tools (time-travel debugging).
    • Supports middleware for async actions.
    • Predictable state flow with reducers.

    ‚ùå Cons

    • More boilerplate compared to Context API.
    • Steeper learning curve.
    • Requires third-party library installation.

    üìä Comparison Table

    Feature React Context Redux
    Built-in Support ‚úÖ Yes ‚ùå No (External Library)
    Use Case Small apps / low-frequency updates Large-scale apps / complex state
    Performance Can suffer with deep trees and frequent updates Better with memoization and selectors
    Boilerplate Minimal More setup (actions, reducers, store)
    Dev Tools No Yes (Redux DevTools)
    Middleware Support No Yes (Thunk, Saga, etc.)

    üîé Summary

    Choose React Context for simple global state sharing (e.g., theme, language, auth). Choose Redux when your application needs complex state, async flows, or you want time-travel debugging and middleware capabilities.

  • ReactJS Security Best Practices

    1. Prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)

    React escapes values by default when rendering, so it protects against most XSS attacks. However, avoid using dangerouslySetInnerHTML unless absolutely necessary.

    • Sanitize any HTML content from external sources before injecting.
    • Prefer using React components and JSX instead of raw HTML strings.

    2. Use HTTPS Everywhere

    Always serve your React app over HTTPS to encrypt data in transit and prevent man-in-the-middle attacks.

    3. Secure Authentication

    • Store tokens (JWT, OAuth tokens) securely, prefer httpOnly cookies over localStorage to prevent XSS token theft.
    • Implement proper logout and token expiration strategies.

    4. Protect Against Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)

    Use CSRF tokens or same-site cookies to protect API endpoints your React app calls.

    5. Avoid Exposing Sensitive Data

    • Never embed secrets, API keys, or private data directly in the React code.
    • Use environment variables and secure backend APIs to handle sensitive info.

    6. Implement Content Security Policy (CSP)

    Configure CSP headers on your server to restrict sources of scripts, styles, and other resources to trusted origins.

    7. Handle Errors Gracefully

    Don‚Äôt leak stack traces or sensitive info in error messages shown to users.

    8. Keep Dependencies Updated

    Regularly update React and related libraries to patch security vulnerabilities.

    Example: Avoid Using dangerouslySetInnerHTML

          <div
        dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{ __html: sanitize(yourHtmlContent) }}
      />

    Use a library like dompurify to sanitize HTML before rendering.

    Useful Libraries

    • DOMPurify - For sanitizing HTML
    • Helmet - For setting secure HTTP headers (used on server)
  • ReactJS Frontend UI Question List

    Here‚Äôs a curated list of ReactJS Frontend UI Developer interview questions tailored for someone with 4 years of experience. These questions range from core concepts to performance optimization and real-world project experience:

    Core React Concepts

    1. What is the Virtual DOM, and how does React use it to improve performance?
    2. Explain the React component lifecycle. How has it changed with hooks?
    3. What are controlled and uncontrolled components in React?
    4. How does the key prop work in lists and why is it important?
    5. Difference between props and state?

    ‚öôÔ∏è React Hooks

    1. How does useEffect work? How do you handle cleanup?
    2. What is the difference between useMemo and useCallback?
    3. When would you use useRef in a real-world project?
    4. How can you mimic componentDidMount behavior using hooks?
    5. Explain custom hooks. Have you created any?

    üß© UI & Component Design ****

    1. How do you design a reusable and customizable button component?
